Ani&mlprime;-Ts&ibreve;&mlprime;ksû—the Chickasaw Indians; singular, Ts&ibreve;&mlprime;ksû.
Ani&mlprime;-Tsi&mlprime;skwa—“Bird people;” one of the seven Cherokee clans.
Ani&mlprime;tsu&mlprime;tsă—“The Boys,” from atsu&mlprime;tsă, boy; the Pleiades. See number 10.
Ani&mlprime;-Wâ&mlprime;d&ibreve;—“Paint people”; one of the seven Cherokee clans.
Ani&mlprime;-Wâdih&ibreve;&mlprime;—“Place of the Paint people or clan”; Paint town, a Cherokee settlement on lower Soco creek, within the reservation in Jackson and Swain counties, North Carolina. It takes its name from the Ani&mlprime;-Wâ&mlprime;d&ibreve; or Paint clan.
ani&mlprime;wani&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—the bugle weed, Lycopus virginicus; literally, “they talk” or “talkers,” from tsiwa&mlprime;nihû, “I am talking,” awani&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, “he talks habitually.” See number 26.
Ani&mlprime;-Wasa&mlprime;s&ibreve;—the Osage Indians; singular, Wasa&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
Ani&mlprime;-Wa&mlprime;&okina;ya—“Wolf people”; the most important of the seven Cherokee clans.
Ani&mlprime;-Yu&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—the Yuchi or Uchee Indians; singular Yu&mlprime;ts&ibreve;.
Ani&mlprime;-Yûñ&mlprime;wiyă&mlprime;—Indians, particularly Cherokee Indians; literally “principal or real people,” from yûñw&ibreve;, person, yă, a suffix implying principal or real, and ani&mlprime;, the tribal prefix. See pages 5 and 182.
Annie Ax—see Saday&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Aquone—a post-office on Nantahala river, in Macon county, North Carolina, site of the former Fort Scott. Probably a corruption of egwân&ibreve;, river.
Arch, John—see Ats&ibreve;.
asâ&mlprime;gwălihû&mlprime;—a pack or burden; asâ&mlprime;gwăl&okina;lû&mlprime; or asâ&mlprime;gw&ibreve;&okina;l&ibreve;, “there is a pack on him.” Cf sâ&mlprime;gwăl&ibreve;&mlprime;.
as&ebreve;h&ibreve;&mlprime;—surely.
As&ebreve;&mlprime;nikă—singular of Ani&mlprime;-S&ebreve;&mlprime;nikă. See Ani&mlprime;-Nûndăwe&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
asga&mlprime;ya—man.
Asga&mlprime;ya Gi&mlprime;găge&ibreve;—the “Red Man”; the Lightning spirit.
asgi&mlprime;na—a ghost, either human or animal; from the fact that ghosts are commonly supposed to be malevolent, the name is frequently rendered “devil.”
Asheville—see Kâsdu&mlprime;y&ibreve; and Unta&mlprime;kiyasti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
âs&ibreve;—the sweat lodge and occasional winter sleeping apartment of the Cherokee and other southern tribes. It was a low-built structure of logs covered with earth, and from its closeness and the fire usually kept smoldering within was known to the old traders as the “hot house.”
â&mlprime;siyu&mlprime; (abbreviated siyu&mlprime;)—good; the common Cherokee salute; gâ&mlprime;siyu&mlprime;, “I am good”; hâ&mlprime;siyu&mlprime;, “thou art good”; â&mlprime;siyu, “he (it) is good”; âstû, “very good” (intensive).
Askwa&mlprime;n&ibreve;—a Spaniard. See Ani&mlprime;skwa&mlprime;n&ibreve;.
âstû&mlprime;—very good; âstû ts&ibreve;k&ibreve;&mlprime;, very good, best of all. Cf â&mlprime;siyu&mlprime;.
Astu&mlprime;gatâ&mlprime;ga—A Cherokee lieutenant in the Confederate service, killed in 1862. See page 170. The name may be rendered, “Standing in the doorway” but implies that the man himself is the door or shutter; it has no first person; gatâ&mlprime;ga, “he is standing”; stu&okina;t&ibreve;, a door or shutter; stuhû&mlprime;, a closed door or passage; stugi&mlprime;st&ibreve;, a key, i.e. something with which to open a door.
asûñ&mlprime;tl&ibreve;, asûñtlûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—a footlog or bridge; literally, “log lying across,” from asi&mlprime;ta, log.
ătă&mlprime;—wood; ata&mlprime;yă, “principal wood,” i.e. oak; cf. Muscogee iti, wood.
Atagâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Gall place,” from ă&mlprime;tăgû&mlprime;, gall, and h&ibreve;, locative; a mythic lake in the Great Smoky mountains. See number 69. The name is also applied to that part of the Great Smoky range centering about Thunderhead mountain and Miry ridge, near the boundary between Swain county, North Carolina, and Blount county, Tennessee.
ă&mlprime;tăgû&mlprime;—gall.
Ătă&mlprime;-gûl&okina;kălû&mlprime;—a noted Cherokee chief, recognized by the British government as the head chief or “emperor” of the Nation, about 1760 and later, and commonly known to the whites as the Little Carpenter (Little Cornplanter, by mistake, in Haywood). The name is frequently spelled Atta-kulla-kulla, Ata-kullakulla or Ata-culculla. It may be rendered “Leaning-wood,” from ătă&mlprime;, “wood” and gûl&okina;kălû, a verb implying that something long is leaning, without sufficient support, against some other object; it has no first person form. Bartram describes him as “a man of remarkably small stature, slender and of a delicate frame, the only instance I saw in the Nation; but he is a man of superior abilities.”
Ata&mlprime;gwa—a Catawba Indian. See Ani&mlprime;la&mlprime;gwă.
A&okina;tâhi&mlprime;ta—abbreviated from A&okina;tâhitûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Place where they shouted,” from gatâ&mlprime;hiû&mlprime;, “I shout,” and y&ibreve;, locative. Waya gap, on the ridge west of Franklin,
Macon county, North. Carolina. See number 13. The map name is probably from the Cherokee wa&okina;ya, wolf.
Ata-kullakulla—see Ătă&mlprime;-gûl&okina;kălû&mlprime;.
â&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;—mountain; in the Lower dialect â&mlprime;tăr&ibreve;, whence the “Ottare” or Upper Cherokee of Adair. The form â&mlprime;tăl&ibreve; is used only in composition; a mountain in situ is âtălûñy&ibreve; or gatu&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
â&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;-gûl&ibreve;&mlprime;—“it climbs the mountain,” i.e., “mountain-climber”; the ginseng plant, Ginseng quinquefolium; from â&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;, mountain, and gûl&ibreve;&mlprime;, “it climbs” (habitually); ts&ibreve;lăh&ibreve;&mlprime; or ts&ibreve;l&ibreve;&mlprime;, “I am climbing.” Also called in the sacred formulas, Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve; Usdi&mlprime;, “Little Man.” See number 126.
a&mlprime;tălulû—unfinished, premature, unsuccessful; whence utalu&mlprime;l&ibreve;, “it is not yet time.”
Ata&mlprime;lûñti&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—a chief of the Arkansas Cherokee about 1818, who had originally emigrated from Tennessee. The name, commonly spelled Tollunteeskee, Taluntiski, Tallotiskee, Tallotuskee, etc., denotes one who throws some living object from a place, as an enemy from a precipice. See number 100 for instance.
â&mlprime;tăr&ibreve;—see â&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;.
ătăs&ibreve;&mlprime; (or ătăsû&mlprime;, in a dialectic form)—a war club.
atatsûñ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—stinging; literally, “he stings” (habitually).
A&okina;tlă&mlprime;nuwă&mlprime;—“Tlă&mlprime;nuwă hole”; the Cherokee name of Chattanooga, Tennessee, (see Tsatănu&mlprime;g&ibreve;) originally applied to a bluff on the south side of the Tennessee river at the foot of the present Market street. See number 124.
A&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—the Cherokee name of John Arch, one of the earliest native writers in the Sequoya characters. The word is simply an attempt at the English name Arch.
atsi&mlprime;la—fire; in the Lower dialect, atsi&mlprime;ra.
Atsil&mlprime;-dihye&mlprime;g&ibreve;—“Fire Carrier”; apparently the Cherokee name for the will-of-the-wisp. See page 335. As is usually the case in Cherokee compounds, the verbal form is plural (“it carries fires”); the singular form is ahye&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
atsil&mlprime;-sûñ&okina;t&ibreve; (abbreviated tsil&mlprime;-sûñ&okina;t&ibreve;)—fleabane (Erigeron canadense); the name signifies “material with which to make fire,” from atsi&mlprime;la, fire, and gasûñ&okina;t&ibreve;, (gatsûñ&okina;t&ibreve; or gatlûñ&okina;t&ibreve;), material with which to make something; from gasûñ&mlprime;skû (or gatlûñ&mlprime;skû), “I make it.” The plant is also called ihyâ&mlprime;ga. See number 126.
Atsil&mlprime;-tlûñtû&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—“Fire panther.” A meteor or comet. See notes to number 9.
Atsi&mlprime;la-wa&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Fire ——”; a mountain, sometimes known as Rattlesnake knob, about two miles northeast of Cherokee, Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
a&mlprime;ts&ibreve;nă&mlprime;—cedar; cf. Muscogee, achena or auchenau.
A&mlprime;ts&ibreve;nă&mlprime;-k&okina;ta&mlprime;ûñ—“Hanging cedar place”; from a&mlprime;tsină&mlprime;, cedar, and k&okina;taûñ, “where it (long) hangs down”; a Cherokee name for the old Taskigi town on Little Tennessee river in Monroe county, Tennessee. See number 105.
atsi&mlprime;ra—see atsi&mlprime;la.
Atsûñ&mlprime;stă&okina;ti&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Atsûñ&mlprime;stă&okina;ti&mlprime;)—“Fire-light place,” (cf. atsil-sûñ&mlprime;&okina;t&ibreve;), referring to the “fire-hunting” method of killing deer in the river at night. The proper form for Chestatee river, near Dahlonega, in Lumpkin county, Georgia.
Attakullakulla—see Ătă-gûl&okina;kălû&mlprime;.
ăwă&mlprime;—see ămă&mlprime;.
awâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;l&ibreve;—eagle; particularly Aquila chrysætus, distinguished as the “pretty-feathered eagle.”
a&okina;w&ibreve;&mlprime;—deer; also sometimes written and pronounced, ăhăw&ibreve;&mlprime;; the name is sometimes applied to the large horned beetle, the “flying stag” of early writers.
a&okina;w&ibreve;&mlprime;-ahănu&mlprime;lăh&ibreve;—goat; literally, “bearded deer.”
a&okina;w&ibreve;&mlprime;-aktă&mlprime;—“deer eye”; the Rudbeckia or black-eyed Susan.
a&okina;w&ibreve;&mlprime;-ahyeli&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—“deer mocker”; the deer bleat, a sort of whistle used by hunters to call the doe by imitating the cry of the fawn.
a&okina;w&ibreve;&mlprime;-e&mlprime;gwă (abbreviated a&okina;w-e&mlprime;gwă)—the elk, literally “great deer.”
a&okina;w&ibreve;&mlprime;-unăde&mlprime;na—sheep; literally “woolly deer.”
A&okina;w&ibreve;&mlprime; Usdi&mlprime;—“Little Deer”; the mythic chief of the Deer tribe. See number 15.
Ax, Annie—see Saday&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Ax, John—see Ităgû&mlprime;năh&ibreve;.
Ayâ&mlprime;sta—“The Spoiler,” from tsiyâ&mlprime;stihû, “I spoil it”; cf. uyâ&mlprime;&ibreve;, bad. A prominent woman and informant on the East Cherokee reservation.
aye&okina;l&ibreve;—half, middle, in the middle.
Ayrate—see e&mlprime;lăd&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Ayuhwa&mlprime;s&ibreve;—the proper form of the name commonly written Hiwassee. It signifies a savanna or meadow and was applied to two (or more) former Cherokee settlements. The more important, commonly distinguished as Ayuhwa&mlprime;s&ibreve; Egwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve; or Great Hiwassee, was on the north bank of Hiwassee river at the present Savannah ford above Columbus, in Polk county, Tennessee. The other was farther up the same river, at the junction of Peachtree creek, above Murphy, in Cherokee county, North Carolina. Lanman writes it Owassa.
A&okina;yûñ&mlprime;in&ibreve;—“Swimmer”; literally, “he is swimming,” from gayûñin&ibreve;&mlprime;, “I am swimming.” A principal priest and informant of the East Cherokee, died in 1899.
Ayûlsû&mlprime;—see Dayûlsûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Beaverdam—see Uy&mlapos;gilâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Big-island—see Ămăye&okina;l-e&mlprime;gwa.
Big-cove—see Kâ&mlprime;lanûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Big-mush—see Gatûñ&mlprime;wa&okina;l&ibreve;.
Big-witch—see Tsk&ibreve;l-e&mlprime;gwa.
Bird-town—see Tsiskwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Bloody-fellow—see Iskagua.
Blythe—see Diskwa&okina;n&ibreve;.
Black-fox—see Inâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
Boudinot, Elias—see Gălăgi&mlprime;na.
Bowl, The; Bowles, Colonel—see Diwa&okina;l&ibreve;.
Brass—see Ûñtsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Brasstown—see Itse&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Breath, The—see Ûñli&mlprime;ta.
Briertown—see Kănu&mlprime;gă&okina;lâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Buffalo (creek)—see Yûnsâ&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Bull-head—see Uskwăle&mlprime;na.
Butler, John—see Tsan&mlprime;uga&mlprime;s&ibreve;tă.
Cade's Cove—see Tsiyâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Canacaught—“Canacaught, the great Conjurer,” mentioned as a Lower Cherokee chief in 1684; possibly kanegwâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;, the water-moccasin snake. See page 31.
Canaly—see hi&mlprime;g&ibreve;na&mlprime;li&ibreve;.
Canasagua—see Gănsâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Cannastion, Cannostee—see Kăna&mlprime;sta.
Canuga—see Kănu&mlprime;ga.
Cartoogaja—see Gatu&mlprime;gitse&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Cataluchee—see Gadalu&mlprime;ts&ibreve;.
Cauchi—a place, apparently in the Cherokee country, visited by Pardo in 1567 (see page 29). The name may possibly have some connection with Nacoochee or Nagu&okina;ts&ibreve;&mlprime;, q.v.
Caunasaita—given as the name of a Lower Cherokee chief in 1684; possibly for Kanûñsi&mlprime;ta, “dogwood” (Cornus florida). See page 31.
Chalaque—see Tsă&mlprime;lăg&ibreve; under “Tribal Synonymy,” page 182.
Chattanooga—see Tsatănu&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Chattooga, Chatuga—see Tsatu&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Cheeowhee—see Tsiyâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Cheerake—see Tsă&mlprime;lăg&ibreve;, under “Tribal Synonymy,” page 182.
Cheowa—see Tsiyâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Cheowa Maximum—see Sehwate&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Cheraqui—see Tsă&mlprime;lăg&ibreve;, under “Tribal Synonymy,” page 182.
Cheraw—see Ani&mlprime;-Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
Cherokee—see Tsă&mlprime;lăg&ibreve;, under “Tribal Synonymy,” page 182; also Elăwâ&mlprime;diy&ibreve;.
Chestatee—see Atsûñ&mlprime;stă&okina;ti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Chestua—see Tsistu&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Cheucunsene—see Tsi&mlprime;yu-gûnsi&mlprime;n&ibreve;.
Cheulah—mentioned by Timberlake as the chief of Settacoo (S&ibreve;&mlprime;tikû) in 1762. The name may be intended for Tsu&okina;lă, “Fox.”
Chickamauga—see Ts&ibreve;&mlprime;kăma&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Chilhowee—see Tsû&okina;lûñ&mlprime;we.
Chimney Tops—see Duni&mlprime;skwa&okina;lgûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Chisca—mentioned in the De Soto narratives as a mining region in the Cherokee country. The name may have a connection with Tsi&mlprime;skwa, “bird,” possibly Tsiskwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, “Bird place.”
Choastea—see Tsistu&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Chopped Oak—see Digălu&mlprime;yătûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Choquata—see Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;.
Chota, Chotte—see Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;.
Citico—see S&ibreve;&mlprime;tikû&mlprime;.
Clear-sky—see Iskagua.
Clennuse—see Tlanusi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Cleveland—see Tsistetsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Coça—see Ani&mlprime;-Ku&mlprime;sa.
Coco—see Kukû&mlprime;.
Cohutta—see Gahû&mlprime;t&ibreve;.
Colanneh, Colona—see Kâ&mlprime;lănû.
Conasauga—see Gănsâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Conneross—see Kăwân&mlprime;-urâ&mlprime;sûñy&ibreve;.
Cooweescoowee—see Gu&mlprime;wisguw&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Coosa—see Ani&mlprime;-Ku&mlprime;sa and Kusă&mlprime;.
Coosawatee—see Ku&mlprime;săweti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Corani—see Kâ&mlprime;lănû.
Cossa—see Ani&mlprime;-Ku&mlprime;sa, Kusa.
Cowee&mlprime;—see Kawi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Coweeta, Coweta—see Ani&mlprime;-Kawi&mlprime;tă.
Coyatee (variously spelled Cawatie, Coiatee, Coytee, Coytoy, Kai-a-tee)—A former Cherokee settlement on Little Tennessee river, some ten miles below the junction of Tellico, about the present Coytee post-office in Loudon county, Tennessee. The correct form and etymology are uncertain.
Creek-path—see Ku&mlprime;să-nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Crow-town—see Kâgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Cuhtahlatah—a Cherokee woman noted in the Wahnenauhi manuscript as having distinguished herself by bravery in battle. The proper form may have some connection with gatûñ&mlprime;lăt&ibreve;, “wild hemp.”
Cullasagee—see Kûlse&mlprime;tsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Cullowhee, Currahee—see Gûlâhi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Cuttawa—see K&ibreve;tu&mlprime;hwă.
dăgan&okina;tû—“he makes it rain”; from aga&mlprime;skă, “it is raining,” aga&mlprime;nă, “it has begun to rain”; a small variety of lizard whose cry is said to presage rain. It is also called a&mlprime;niganti&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, “they make it rain” (plural form), or “rain-maker.” See number 59.
dagûl&okina;kû—the American white-fronted goose (Anser albifrons gambeli). The name may be an onomatope. See number 6.
dăgû&mlprime;nă—the fresh water mussel; also a variety of face pimples.
Dăgûnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Mussel place,” from dăgû&mlprime;nă, mussel, and h&ibreve;, locative. The Muscle shoals on Tennessee river, in northwestern Alabama. It was sometimes called also simply Tsu&okina;stănalûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Shoals place.” Cf. U&okina;stăna&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
Dăgû&mlprime;năwe&mlprime;lâh&ibreve;—“Mussel-liver place,” from dăgû&mlprime;nă, mussel, uwe&mlprime;la, liver, and h&ibreve;, locative; the Cherokee name for the site of Nashville, Tennessee. No reason can now be given for the name.
Dahlonega—A town in Lumpkin County, Georgia, near which the first gold was mined. A mint was established there in 1838. The name is from the Cherokee dală&mlprime;nige&mlprime;i, yellow, whence ate&mlprime;lă-dalâ&mlprime;nige&mlprime;i, “yellow money,” i.e., gold.
daksăwa&mlprime;ihû—“he is shedding tears.”
dăkwă&mlprime;—a mythic great fish; also the whale. See number 68.
Dăkwă&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Dăkwă place,” from a tradition of a dăkwă&mlprime; in the river at that point. A former Cherokee settlement, known to the traders as Toqua or Toco, on Little Tennessee river, about the mouth of Toco creek in Monroe county, Tennessee. See number 68. A similar name and tradition attaches to a spot on the French Broad river, about six miles above the Warm springs, in Buncombe county, North Carolina. See number 122.
dakwa&mlprime;nitlastest&ibreve;—“I shall have them on my legs for garters”; from anitla&mlprime;st&ibreve; (plural dinitla&mlprime;st&ibreve;), garter; d-, initial plural; akwă, first person particle; and est&ibreve;, future suffix. See number 77.
da&mlprime;l&ibreve;kstă&mlprime;—“vomiter,” from dagik&mlprime;stihû&mlprime;, “I am vomiting,” dalikstă&mlprime;, “he vomits” (habitually); the form is plural. The spreading adder (Heterodon), also sometimes called kwandăya&mlprime;hû, a word of uncertain etymology.
Da&mlprime;&okina;năgâstă—for Da&mlprime;&okina;năwă-gâsta&mlprime;yă, “Sharp-war,” i.e. “Eager-warrior”; a Cherokee woman's name.
Da&mlprime;&okina;nawa-(a)sa&okina;tsûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve; “War ford,” from da&mlprime;&okina;nawa, war, and asa&okina;tsûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, a crossing-place or ford. A ford on Cheowa river about three miles below Robbinsville, in Graham county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Danda&mlprime;gănû&mlprime;—“Two looking at each other,” from detsi&mlprime;gănû&mlprime;, “I am looking at him.” A former Cherokee settlement, commonly known as Lookout Mountain town, on Lookout Mountain creek, near the present Trenton, Dade county, Georgia. One of the Chickamauga towns (see Ts&ibreve;&mlprime;kăma&mlprime;gi), so called on account of the appearance of the mountains facing each other across the Tennessee river at Chattanooga.
Da&mlprime;si&okina;giya&mlprime;g&ibreve;—an old masculine personal name, of doubtful etymology, but commonly rendered by the traders “Shoe-boots,” possibly referring to some peculiar style of moccasin or leggin. A chief known to the whites as Shoe-boots is mentioned in the Revolutionary records. Chief Lloyd Welch, of the eastern band, was known in the tribe as Da&mlprime;si&okina;giya&mlprime;g&ibreve; and the same name is now used by the East Cherokee as the equivalent of the name Lloyd.
Da&mlprime;skw&ibreve;tûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Rafters place,” from daskwitûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, “rafters,” and y&ibreve;, locative. A former settlement on Tusquittee creek, near Hayesville, in Clay county, North Carolina.
dasûñ&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;—ant; dasûñ&mlprime;tăl&ibreve; atatsûñ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, “stinging ant,” the large red cow-ant (Myrmica?), also called sometimes, on account of its hard body-case, nûñ&mlprime;yunu&mlprime;w&ibreve;, “stone-clad,” after the fabulous monster. See number 67.
Datle&mlprime;yăsta&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Where they fell down,” a point on Tuckasegee river, a short distance above Webster, in Jackson county, North Carolina. For tradition see number 122.
dâts&ibreve;—a traditional water monster. See number 122.
Dâtsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Dâts&ibreve; place”; a place on Little Tennessee river, near the junction of Eagle creek, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Datsu&mlprime;nălâsgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“where there are tracks or footprints,” from ulâ&mlprime;sinûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve; or ulâsgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, footprint. Track Rock gap, near Blairsville, Georgia. Also sometimes called De&mlprime;găyelûñ&mlprime;hă, “place of branded marks”; (digăletănûñ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, branded, or printed). See number 125.
dâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—beaver.
Dayûlsûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Place where they cried,” a spot on the ridge at the head of Tuckasegee river, in Jackson county, North Carolina; so called from an old tradition. See number 80.
dâ&mlprime;yuni&mlprime;s&ibreve;—“beaver's grandchild,” from dâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, beaver, and uni&mlprime;s&ibreve;, son's child, of either sex (daughter's child, either sex, uli&mlprime;s&ibreve;). The water beetle or mellow bug (Dineutes discolor).
Degal&okina;gûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—a cairn, literally “Where they are piled up”; a series of cairns on the south side of Cheowa river, in Graham county, North Carolina. See number 122.
De&mlprime;gătâ&mlprime;gă—The Cherokee name of General Stand Watie and of a prominent early western chief known to the whites as Takatoka. The word is derived from tsitâ&mlprime;gă, “I am standing,” da&okina;nitâ&mlprime;gă, “they are standing together,” and conveys the subtle meaning of two persons standing together and so closely united in sympathy as to form but one human body.
De&mlprime;găyelûñ&mlprime;hă—see Datsu&mlprime;nalâsgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
detsănûñ&mlprime;l&ibreve;—an inclosure or piece of level ground cleared for ceremonial purposes; applied more particularly to the Green-corn dance ground. The word has a plural form, but can not be certainly analyzed.
De&mlprime;tsătă—a Cherokee sprite. See number 78.
detsinu&mlprime;lăhûñgû&mlprime;—“I tried, but failed.”
Dida&okina;lâski&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Showering place.” In the story (number 17) the name is understood to mean “The place where it rains fire.” It signifies literally, however, the place where it showers, or comes down, and lodges upon something animate, and has no definite reference to fire (atsi&mlprime;la) or rain (agăskă, “it is raining”); dega&okina;lâskû&mlprime;, “they are showering down and lodging upon him.”
Dida&mlprime;skasti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they were afraid of each other.” A spot on Little Tennessee river, near the mouth of Alarka creek, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
diga&mlprime;gwăn&ibreve;&mlprime;—the mud-hen or didapper (Gallinula galeata). The name is a plural form and implies “lame,” or “crippled in the legs” (cf. detsi&mlprime;nigwă&mlprime;nă, “I am kneeling”), probably from the bouncing motion of the bird when in the water. It is also the name of a dance.
Diga&mlprime;kati&mlprime;y&ibreve;—see Gakati&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
di&mlprime;gălûñgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“where it rises, or comes up”; the east. The sacred term is Nûñdâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, q.v.
digălûñ&mlprime;lătiyûñ—a height, one of a series, from galûn&mlprime;lăt&ibreve;, “above.” See number 1.
Digălu&mlprime;yătûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where it is gashed (with hatchets)”; from tsilu&mlprime;yû, “I am cutting (with a chopping stroke),” di, plural prefix, and y&ibreve;, locative. The Chopped Oak, formerly east of Clarkesville, Georgia. See number 125.
Digăne&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—“He picks them up” (habitually), from ts&ibreve;ne&mlprime;û, “I am picking it up.” A Cherokee Union soldier in the civil war. See page 171.
digi&mlprime;găge&mlprime;&ibreve;—the plural of gi&mlprime;găge&mlprime;&ibreve;, red.
digû&mlprime;lanăhi&mlprime;ta—for digû&mlprime;l&ibreve;-anăhi&mlprime;ta, “having long ears,” “long-eared”; from gûl&ebreve;, “ear” and gûnahi&mlprime;ta, “long.”
Dihyûñ&mlprime;dulă&mlprime;—“Sheaths,” or “Scabbards”; singular ahyûñ&mlprime;dulă&mlprime;, “a gun sheath,” or other scabbard. The probable correct form of a name which appears in Revolutionary documents as “Untoola, or Gun Rod.”
diktă&mlprime;—plural of aktă&mlprime;, eye.
d&ibreve;lă&mlprime;—skunk.
dilsta&mlprime;ya&okina;t&ibreve;—“scissors”; the water-spider (Dolomedes).
dinda&mlprime;skwate&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—the violet; the name signifies, “they pull each other's heads off.”
dine&mlprime;tlănă—the creation.
di&okina;nûsk&ibreve;—“the breeder”; a variety of smilax brier. See number 126.
Disgâ&mlprime;gisti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they gnaw”; a place on Cheowa river, in Graham county, North Carolina. See number 122.
diskwa&okina;n&ibreve;—“chestnut bread,” i.e., a variety of bread having chestnuts mixed with it. The Cherokee name of James Blythe, interpreter and agency clerk.
distai&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“they are strong,” plural of astai&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “strong, or tough.” The Tephrosia or devil's-shoestring. See number 126.
dista&mlprime;st&ibreve;—a mill (generic).
dita&mlprime;stayesk&ibreve;—“a barber,” literally “one who cuts things” (as with a scissors), from tsista&mlprime;yû, “I cut,” (as with a scissors). The cricket (tăla&mlprime;tŭ) is sometimes so called. See number 59.
Diwa&mlprime;&okina;l&ibreve;—“Bowl,” a prominent chief of the western Cherokee, known to the whites as The Bowl, or Colonel Bowles, killed by the Texans in 1839. The chief mentioned on page 100 may have been another of the same name.
diyâ&mlprime;hăl&ibreve; (or duyâ&mlprime;hăl&ibreve;)—the alligator lizard (Sceloporue undulalus). See number 59.
Diyâ&mlprime;hăli&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Lizard place,” from diyâ&mlprime;hăl&ibreve;, lizard, and y&ibreve;, locative. Joanna bald, a mountain at the head of Valley river, on the line between Cherokee and Graham counties, North Carolina. For tradition see number 122; also number 59.
Double-head—see Tăl-tsu&mlprime;skă&mlprime;.
Dragging-canoe—see Tsi&mlprime;yu-gûnsi&mlprime;n&ibreve;.
Dudûñ&mlprime;leksûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where its legs were broken off”; a place on Tuckasegee river, a few miles above Webster, in Jackson county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Dugilu&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Dugilu&mlprime;, and commonly written Tugaloo, or sometimes Toogelah or Toogoola)—a name occurring in several places in the old Cherokee country, the best known being Tugaloo river, so called from a former Cherokee settlement of that name situated at the junction of Toccoa creek with the main stream, in Habersham county, Georgia. The word is of uncertain etymology, but seems to refer to a place at the forks of a stream.
Dûksa&mlprime;&ibreve;, Dûkw&okina;sa&mlprime;&ibreve;—The correct form of the name commonly written Toxaway, applied to a former Cherokee settlement in South Carolina, and the creek upon which it stood, an extreme head-stream of Keowee river having its source in Jackson county, North Carolina. The meaning of the name is lost, although it has been wrongly interpreted to mean “Place of shedding tears.” See number 123.
Dulastûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Potsherd place.” A former Cherokee settlement on Nottely river in Cherokee county, North Carolina. See number 122.
dule&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—“kernels,” a goitrous swelling upon the throat.
dulu&mlprime;s&ibreve;—a variety of frog found upon the headwaters of Savannah river. See number 125.
Duniya&okina;ta&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where there are shelves, or flat places,” from aya&okina;te&mlprime;n&ibreve;, flat, whence da&mlprime;ya&okina;tana&okina;lûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;&mlprime;, a shelf, and y&ibreve;&mlprime;, the locative. A gap on the Great Smoky range, near Clingman's dome, Swain county, North Carolina. See notes to number 100.
Dunidû&mlprime;lalûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they made arrows”; a place on Straight creek, a head-stream of Oconaluftee river, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Duni&mlprime;skwa&okina;lgûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;—the double peak known as the Chimney Tops, in the Great Smoky mountains about the head of Deep creek, in Swain county, North Carolina. On the north side is the pass known as Indian gap. The name signifies a “forked antler,” from uskwa&okina;lgû, antler, but indicates that the antler is attached in place, as though the deer itself were concealed below.
Du&mlprime;stăyalûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where it made a noise as of thunder or shooting,” apparently referring to a lightning stroke (detsistăya&mlprime;hihû, “I make a shooting, or thundering, noise,” might be a first person form used by the personified Thunder-god); a spot on Hiwassee river, about the junction of Shooting creek, near Hayesville, in Clay county, North Carolina. A former settlement along the creek bore the same name. See number 79.
du&mlprime;stu&mlprime;—a species of frog, appearing very early in spring; the name is intended for an onomatope. It is the correct form of the name of the chief noted by McKenney and Hall as “Tooantuh or Spring Frog.”
Dutch—see Tăts&ibreve;&mlprime;.
duw&ebreve;&okina;gă—the spring lizard. See number 59.
Eagle dance—see Tsugidû&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime; Ûlsgi&mlprime;st&ibreve;.
Eastinaulee—see U&okina;stăna&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
Echoee—see Itse&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Echota—see Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;.
Edâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“He goes about” (habitually); a masculine name.
Echota, New—see Gănsâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
edâ&mlprime;tă—my father (Upper dialect); the Middle and Lower dialect form is agidâ&mlprime;tă.
edu&mlprime;tŭ—my maternal grandfather (Upper dialect); the Middle and Lower dialect form is agidu&mlprime;tŭ; cf. eni&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
e&mlprime;gwa—great; cf. u&mlprime;tănû.
egwâ&mlprime;n&ibreve;—river.
Egwânul&okina;t&ibreve;—“By the river,” from egwâ&mlprime;n&ibreve;, river, and nu&mlprime;lăt&ibreve; or nul&okina;t&ibreve;, near, beside. The proper form of Oconaluftee, the name of the river flowing through the East Cherokee reservation in Swain and Jackson counties, North Carolina. The Cherokee town, “Oconalufte,” mentioned by Bartram as existing about 1775, was probably on the lower course of the river at the present Birdtown, on the reservation, where was formerly a considerable mound.
elă—earth, ground.
e&mlprime;lăd&ibreve;&mlprime;—low, below; in the Lower dialect e&mlprime;răd&ibreve;&mlprime;, whence the Ayrate or Lower Cherokee of Adair as distinguished from the Ottare (â&mlprime;tăr&ibreve;, â&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;) or Upper Cherokee.
elanti—a song form for e&mlprime;lăd&ibreve;, q.v.
Elătse&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Elătse&mlprime;)—possibly “Green (Verdant) earth,” from elă, earth, and itse&mlprime;y&ibreve;, green, from fresh-springing vegetation. The name of several former Cherokee settlements, commonly known to the whites as Ellijay, Elejoy or Allagae. One of these was upon the headwaters of Keowee river in South Carolina; another was on Ellijay creek of Little Tennessee river, near the present Franklin, in Macon county, North Carolina; another was about the present Ellijay in Gilmer county, Georgia; and still another was on Ellejoy creek of Little river near the present Maryville, in Blount county, Tennessee.
Elăwâ&mlprime;diy&ibreve; (abbreviated Elăwâ&mlprime;di)—“Red-earth place” from elă, earth, wâdi, brown-red or red paint, and y&ibreve;, the locative. 1. The Cherokee name of Yellow-hill settlement, now officially known as Cherokee, the postoffice and agency headquarters for the East Cherokee, on Oconaluftee river in Swain county, North Carolina. 2. A former council ground, known in history as Red Clay, at the site of the present village of that name in Whitfield county, Georgia, adjoining the Tennessee line.
Ellijay—see Elătse&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
eni&mlprime;s&ibreve;—my paternal grandfather (Upper dialect); the Middle and Lower dialect form is agini&mlprime;s&ibreve;. Cf. edu&mlprime;tŭ.
Eskaqua—see Iskagua.
Estanaula, Estinaula—see U&okina;stăna&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
&Ebreve;tăwa&mlprime;hă-tsistatla&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—“Deadwood-lighter,” a traditional Cherokee conjurer. See number 100.
e&okina;t&ibreve;, or et&ibreve;—old, long ago.
Etowah—see I&mlprime;tăwă&mlprime;.
Etsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime;—see Ûñtsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime;.
ets&ibreve;&mlprime;—my mother (Upper dialect); the Middle and Lower dialect form is agits&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Euharlee—see Yuha&mlprime;l&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Feather dance—see Tsugidû&okina;l&ibreve;, Ûlsgi&mlprime;st&ibreve;.
Fighting-town—see Walâs&mlprime;-unûlsli&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Flax-toter—see Tâle&mlprime;danigi&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Flying-squirrel—see Kâ&mlprime;lahû&mlprime;.
French Broad—see Unta&mlprime;kiyasti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Frogtown—see Walâsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Gadalu&mlprime;lŭ—the proper name of the mountain known to the whites as Yonah (from yânû, “bear”), or upper Chattahoochee river, in White county, Georgia. The name has no connection with Tallulah (see Tălulŭ&mlprime;), and can not be translated.
Gadalu&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—in the corrupted form of Cataluchee this appears on the map as the name of a peak, or rather a ridge, on the line between Swain and Haywood counties, in North Carolina, and of a creek running down on the Haywood side into Big Pigeon river. It is properly the name of the ridge only and seems to refer to a “fringe standing erect,” apparently from the appearance of the timber growing in streaks along the side of the mountain; from wadălu&mlprime;yătă, fringe, gadû&mlprime;tă, “standing up in a row or series.”
găhăwi&mlprime;sita—parched corn; improperly spelled wissactaw by Hawkins. See note under number 83.
Gahût&ibreve; (Gahû&mlprime;tă and Gwahû&mlprime;t&ibreve; in dialectic forms)—Cohutta mountain, in Murray county, Georgia. The name comes from gahûtâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “a shed roof supported on poles,” and refers to a fancied resemblance in the summit.
Gakăti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Place of setting free”; sometimes spoken in the plural form, Diga&mlprime;kăti&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Place of setting them free.” A point on Tuckasegee river about three miles above Bryson City, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
gaktûñ&mlprime;ta—an injunction, command or rule, more particularly a prohibition or ceremonial tabu. Tsiga&okina;te&mlprime;gû, “I am observing an injunction, or tabu”; adakte&mlprime;g&ibreve;, “he is under tabu regulations.”
Gălăgi&mlprime;na—a male deer (buck) or turkey (gobbler); in the first sense the name is sometimes used also for the large horned beetle (Dynastes tityus?). The Indian name of Elias Boudinot, first Cherokee editor. See page 111.
găli&mlprime;sgisidâ&mlprime;hû—I am dancing about; from găli&mlprime;sgiă&mlprime;, “I am dancing,” and edâhû&mlprime;, “I am going about.”
gălûñkw&mlprime;ti&mlprime;yu—honored, sacred; used in the bible to mean holy, hallowed.
gălûñ&mlprime;lăt&ibreve;—above, on high.
găne&mlprime;ga—skin.
ganidawâ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—the campion, catchfly or “rattlesnake's master” (Silene stellata); the name signifies “it disjoints itself,” from ganidawâskû&mlprime;, “it is unjointing itself,” on account of the peculiar manner in which the dried stalk breaks off at the joints.
Gănsâ&mlprime;g&ibreve; (or Gănsâgiy&ibreve;)—the name of several former settlements in the old Cherokee country; it cannot be analyzed. One town of this name was upon Tuckasegee river, a short distance above the present Webster, in Jackson county, North Carolina; another was on the lower part of Canasauga creek, in McMinn county, Tennessee; a third was at the junction of Conasauga and Coosawatee rivers, where afterward was located the Cherokee capital, New Echota, in Gordon
county, Georgia; a fourth, mentioned in the De Soto narratives as Canasoga or Canasagua, was located in 1540 on the upper Chattahoochee river, possibly in the neighborhood of Kenesaw mountain, Georgia (see page 197).
Gănsa&okina;ti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Robbing place,” from tsina&mlprime;sahûñskû&mlprime;, “I am robbing him.” Vengeance creek of Valley river, in Cherokee county, North Carolina. The name Vengeance was originally a white man's nickname for an old Cherokee woman, of forbidding aspect, who lived there before the Removal. See number 122.
Găns&ebreve;&okina;t&ibreve;—a rattle; as the Cherokee dance rattle is made from a gourd the masculine name, Găns&ebreve;&okina;t&ibreve;, is usually rendered by the whites, “Rattling-gourd.”
gatayûst&ibreve;—the wheel and stick game of the southern tribes, incorrectly called nettecawaw by Timberlake. See note under number 3.
Gâtegwâ&mlprime;—for Gâtegwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, possibly a contraction of Igât(&ibreve;)-egwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, “Great-swamp (-thicket) place.” A high peak southeast from Franklin, Macon county, North Carolina, and perhaps identical with Fodderstack mountain. See number 75.
ga&mlprime;tsû—see hatlû&mlprime;.
Gatu&mlprime;gitse&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Gatu&mlprime;gitse&mlprime;)—“New-settlement place,” from gatu&mlprime;g&ibreve; or sgatu&mlprime;g&ibreve;, town, settlement, itse&mlprime;h&ibreve;, new, especially applied to new vegetation, and y&ibreve;, the locative. A former settlement on Cartoogaja creek of Little Tennessee river, above Franklin, in Macon county, North Carolina.
Gatuti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Town-building place,” or “Settlement place,” from gatu&mlprime;g&ibreve;, a settlement, and y&ibreve;, locative. A place on Santeetla creek, near Robbinsville, in Graham county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Gatûñ&mlprime;lti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Hemp place,” from gatûñ&mlprime;lăt&ibreve;, “wild hemp” (Apocynum cannabinum), and y&ibreve;, locative. A former Cherokee settlement, commonly known as Hemptown, on the creek of the same name, near Morganton, in Fannin county, Georgia.
Gatûñ&mlprime;wa&okina;l&ibreve;—a noted western Cherokee about 1842, known to the whites as “Hard-mush” or “Big-mush.” Gatûñ&mlprime;wa&okina;l&ibreve;, from ga&mlprime;tŭ&mlprime;, “bread,” and ûñwa&mlprime;&okina;l&ibreve;, “made into balls or lumps,” is a sort of mush of parched corn meal, made very thick, so that it can be dipped out in lumps almost of the consistency of bread.
ge&mlprime;&ibreve;—down stream, down the road, with the current; tsâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;, up stream.
gese&mlprime;&ibreve;—was; a separate word which, when used after the verb in the present tense, makes it past tense without change of form; in the form hi&mlprime;gese&mlprime;&ibreve; it usually accompanies an emphatic repetition.
Ge&okina;yăgu&mlprime;ga (for Age&mlprime;hyă-guga?)—a formulistic name for the moon (nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime;); it cannot be analyzed, but seems to contain the word age&mlprime;hyă, “woman.” See also nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime;.
gigă—blood; cf. gi&mlprime;găge&mlprime;&ibreve;, red.
gi&mlprime;gă-danegi&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—“blood taker,” from gigă, blood, and ada&mlprime;negi&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, “one who takes liquids,” from tsi&mlprime;negiă&mlprime;, “I am taking it” (liquid). Another name for the tsâne&mlprime;n&ibreve; or scorpion lizard. See number 59.
gi&mlprime;găge&mlprime;&ibreve;—red, bright red, scarlet; the brown-red of certain animals and clays is distinguished as wâ&mlprime;dige&mlprime;&ibreve;.
gi&mlprime;gă-tsuha&mlprime;&okina;l&ibreve;—“bloody-mouth,” literally, “having blood on the corners of his mouth”; from gigă, blood, and tsuhănûñsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;, the corners of the mouth (ăha&mlprime;l&ibreve;, his mouth). A large lizard, probably the Pleistodon. See number 59.
gi&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;—dog; in the Lower dialect, gi&okina;r&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Gi&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;-din&ebreve;hûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the dogs live,” from gi&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;, dog, din&ebreve;hû&mlprime;, “they dwell” (&ebreve;hû, “I dwell”), and y&ibreve;, locative. A place on Oconaluftee river, a short distance above Cherokee, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Gi&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;-utsûñ&mlprime;stănuñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the dog ran,” from gi&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;, dog, and utsûñ&mlprime;stănûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “footprints made by an animal running”; the Milky Way. See number 11.
ginûnti—a song form for ginû&mlprime;ti&ibreve;&mlprime;, “to lay him (animate object) upon the ground.” See number 75.
gi&okina;r&ibreve;&mlprime;—see gi&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Gisehûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the female lives,” from agi&mlprime;s&ibreve;, female, and y&ibreve;, the locative. A place on Tuckasegee river, a short distance above Bryson City, Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
gitlû&mlprime;—hair (Upper dialect); in the Middle and Lower dialects, gitsû&mlprime;.
gitsû&mlprime;—see gitlû&mlprime;.
Glass, The—see Ta&mlprime;gwădihi&mlprime;.
Gohoma—A Lower Cherokee chief in 1684; the form cannot be identified. See page 31.
Going-snake—see I&mlprime;nădûna&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Gorhaleke—a Lower Cherokee chief in 1684; the form cannot be identified. See page 31.
Great island—see Ămăye&okina;l-e&mlprime;gwa.
Gregory bald—see Tsistu&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Guachoule—see Guaxule.
Guaquili (Wakili)—a town in the Cherokee country, visited by De Soto in 1540, and again in 1567 by Pardo, who calls it Aguaquiri (see pages 25 and 28). The name may have a connection with wagul&ibreve;&mlprime;, “whippoorwill,” or with u-)wâ&mlprime;gi&okina;l&ibreve;, “foam.”
Guasula—see Guaxule.
Guasili—see Guaxule.
Guaxule—a town in the Cherokee country, visited by De Soto in 1540; variously spelled in the narratives, Guasili, Guachoule, Guasula, Guaxule, Quaxule, etc. It was probably about at Nacoochee mound, in White county, Georgia. It has been suggested that the Spaniards may have changed the Indian name to resemble that of a town in Spain. See pages 26 and 194.
gû&mlprime;daye&mlprime;wû—“I have sewed myself together”; “I am sewing,” tsiye&mlprime;wiă&mlprime;; “I am sewing myself together,” gûdayewiû. See number 31.
gŭgw&ebreve;&mlprime; (or g&okina;gw&ebreve;&mlprime;)—the quail or partridge; the name is an onomatope.
gŭgw&ebreve;&mlprime;-ulasu&mlprime;la—“partridge moccasin,” from gŭgw&ebreve;&mlprime; or g&okina;gw&ebreve;&mlprime;, partridge, and ulasula, moccasin or shoe; the ladyslipper (Cypripedium).
Gûlâhi&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Gûlâhi&mlprime;, or Gûrâhi&mlprime;, in the Lower dialect)—“Gûlâ&mlprime;h&ibreve; place,” so called from an unidentified spring plant eaten as a salad by the Cherokee. The name of two or more places in the old Cherokee country; one about Currahee mountain in Habersham county, Georgia, the other on Cullowhee river, an upper branch of Tuckasegee, in Jackson county, North Carolina. Currahee Dick was a noted chief about the year 1820.
Gû&mlprime;lani&mlprime;y&ibreve;—a Cherokee and Natchez settlement formerly about the junction of Brasstown creek with Hiwassee river, a short distance above Murphy, in Cherokee county, North Carolina. The etymology of the word is doubtful.
gul&ebreve;&mlprime;—acorn.
gûl&ebreve;&mlprime;-diska&okina;nih&ibreve;&mlprime;—the turtle-dove; literally, “it cries, or mourns, for acorns,” from gul&ebreve;&mlprime;, acorn, and diska&okina;nih&ibreve;&mlprime;, “it cries for them” (di-, plural prefix, -hi, habitual suffix). The turtle-dove feeds upon acorns and its cry somewhat resembles the name, gul&ebreve;&mlprime;.
gûle&mlprime;g&ibreve;—“climber,” from tsilah&ibreve;&mlprime;, “I climb” (second person, h&ibreve;&mlprime;lah&ibreve;&mlprime;; third person, gûlah&ibreve;&mlprime;); the blacksnake (Bascanion constrictor).
Gûl&okina;kăla&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—An earlier name for Tsunu&mlprime;lăhûñ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, q.v.
gûl&okina;kwâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;—seven; also the mole-cricket (Gryllotalpa). See number 59.
gûl&okina;kwâ&mlprime;gine(-&ibreve;—seventh; from gûl&okina;kwâg&ibreve;, seven.
Gûlsădih&ibreve;&mlprime; (or Gûltsădih&ibreve;&mlprime;?)—a masculine personal name, of uncertain etymology.
Gumlog—see Tsilalu&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
gûnăhi&mlprime;ta—long.
Gû&mlprime;năhitûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Long place” (i.e., Long valley), from gûnăhita, long, and y&ibreve;, locative. A former settlement, known to the whites as Valleytown, where now is the town of the same name, on Valley river, in Cherokee county, North Carolina. The various settlements on Valley river and the adjacent part of Hiwassee were known collectively as the “Valley towns.”
Gûn&mlprime;-d&ibreve;&mlprime;gaduhûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Gûn&mlprime;-d&ibreve;gadu&mlprime;hûñ)—“Turkey settlement” (gû&mlprime;nă, turkey), so called from the chief, Turkey or Little Turkey. A former settlement, known to the whites as Turkeytown, upon the west bank of Coosa river, opposite the present Center, in Cherokee county, Alabama.
gû&mlprime;nî&mlprime;—arrow. Cf. Seneca ga&mlapos;na&mlapos;.
gûñ&mlprime;năge&mlprime;&ibreve; (or gûñ&mlprime;năge)—black.
Gûñn&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;—see Nûñn&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Gûñskăli&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—a masculine personal name of uncertain etymology.
Gunters landing, Guntersville—see Ku&mlprime;să-Nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Gûn-tsuskwa&mlprime;&okina;l&ibreve;—“Short arrows,” from gûn&ibreve;&mlprime;, arrow, and tsuskwa&mlprime;&okina;l&ibreve;, plural of uskwa&mlprime;&okina;l&ibreve;, short; a traditional western tribe. See number 105.
Gûnûñ&mlprime;da&okina;le&mlprime;g&ibreve;—see Nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;-dih&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Gust&ibreve;&mlprime;—a traditional Cherokee settlement on Tennessee river, near Kingston, Roane county, Tennessee. See number 79. The name cannot be analyzed. Wafford thought it a Cherokee attempt at “Kingston,” but it seems rather to be aboriginal.
Gu&mlprime;wisguw&ibreve;&mlprime;—The Cherokee name for the chief John Ross and for the district named in his honor, commonly spelled Cooweescoowee. Properly an onomatope for a large bird said to have been seen formerly at infrequent intervals in the old Cherokee country, accompanying the migratory wild geese, and described as resembling a large snipe, with yellow legs and unwebbed feet. In boyhood John Ross was known as Tsan&mlprime;-usdi&mlprime;, “Little John.”
Gwal&okina;gâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Frog place,” from gwal&okina;gû, a variety of frog, and h&ibreve;, locative. A place on Hiwassee river, just above the junction of Peachtree creek, near Murphy, in Cherokee county, North Carolina; about 1755 the site of a village of refugee Natchez, and later of a Baptist mission.
gwehe&mlprime;!—a cricket's cry. See number 119.
ha!—an introductory exclamation intended to attract attention or add emphasis; about equivalent to Here! Now!
ha&mlprime;-ma&mlprime;ma&mlprime;—a song term compounded of ha! an introductory exclamation, and mămă&mlprime;, a word which has no analysis, but is used in speaking to young children to mean “let me carry you on my back.” See number 117.
Hanging-maw—see Uskwâ&mlprime;li-gû&mlprime;tă.
ha&mlprime;nia-l&ibreve;l&mlprime;-l&ibreve;l&mlprime;—an unmeaning dance refrain. See number 24.
Hard-mush—see Gatûñ&mlprime;wa&okina;l&ibreve;.
ha&mlprime;suyak&mlprime;—a song form for hasuya&mlprime;g&ibreve;&mlprime;, “(thou) pick it out” (imperative); “I pick it out, or select it,” ga&mlprime;suyăgiû&mlprime;; second person, ha&mlprime;suyăgiû&mlprime;. See number 19.
ha&mlprime;tlû—dialectic form, ga&mlprime;tsû, “where?” (interrogative).
ha&mlprime;wiye&mlprime;&ebreve;h&ibreve;&mlprime;, ha&mlprime;wiye&mlprime;-hyuwe&mlprime;—unmeaning dance refrains. See numbers 32 and 118.
hayû&mlprime;—an emphatic affirmative, about equivalent to “Yes, sir!” See number 115.
hayuya&mlprime;haniwă&mlprime;—an unmeaning refrain in one of the bear songs. See number 75.
he-e!—an unmeaning song introduction.
Hemp-carrier—see Tâle&mlprime;danigi&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Hemptown—see Gatûñlti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
hi!—unmeaning dance exclamation.
hi&mlprime;g&ibreve;na&mlprime;li&ibreve;—“(you are) my friend”; agina&mlprime;li&ibreve;, “(he is) my friend.” In white man's jargon, canaly.
Hickory-log—see Wane&mlprime;-asûñ&mlprime;tlûñy&ibreve;.
Hightower—see I&mlprime;tăwă&mlprime;.
h&ibreve;la&mlprime;gû?—how many? how much? (Upper dialect); the Middle dialect form is hûñgû&mlprime;.
h&ibreve;lahi&mlprime;yu—long ago; the final yu makes it more emphatic.
hi&mlprime;lûñnû—“(thou) go to sleep”; from ts&ibreve;&mlprime;lihû&mlprime;, “I am asleep.”
h&ibreve;&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—five; cf. Mohawk w&ibreve;sk. The Cherokee numerals including 10 are as follows: sâ&mlprime;gwû, tă&mlprime;l&ibreve;, tsâ&mlprime;&ibreve;, nûñ&mlprime;g&ibreve;, h&ibreve;&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, su&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;, gûl&okina;kwâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;, tsune&mlprime;la, sañne&mlprime;la, askâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Hiwassee—see Ayuhwa&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
hi&mlprime;yagu&mlprime;w&ebreve;—an unmeaning dance refrain. See number 32.
Houston, Samuel—see Kă&mlprime;lănû.
hûñgû—see h&ibreve;la&mlprime;gû.
huhu—the yellow-breasted chat, or yellow mocking bird (Icteria virens); the name is an onomatope. See number 45.
hûñyahu&mlprime;skă—“he will die.”
hw&ibreve;&mlprime;lah&ibreve;—“thou (must) go.”
igăgû&mlprime;t&ibreve;—daylight. The name is sometimes applied to the ulûñsû&mlprime;t&ibreve; (q.v.), and also to the clematis vine.
i&mlprime;hya—the cane reed (Arundinaria) of the Gulf states, used by the Indians for blowguns, fishing rods, and basketry.
ihyâ&mlprime;ga—see atsil&mlprime;sûñ&okina;t&ibreve;.
i&mlprime;nădû&mlprime;—snake.
I&mlprime;nădû-na&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Going-snake,” a Cherokee chief prominent about eighty years ago. The name properly signifies that the person is “going along in company with a snake,” the verbal part being from the irregular verb asta&mlprime;&ibreve;, “I am going along with him.” The name has been given to a district of the present Cherokee Nation.
i&mlprime;năg&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;—dwelling in the wilderness, an inhabitant of the wilderness; from i&mlprime;năge&mlprime;&ibreve;, “wilderness,” and &ebreve;h&ibreve;, habitual present form of &ebreve;hû, “he is dwelling”; g&ebreve;&mlprime;û, “I am dwelling.”
I&mlprime;năge-utăsûñ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“He who grew up in the wilderness,” i.e. “He who grew up wild”; from i&mlprime;năge&mlprime;&ibreve;, “wilderness, unoccupied timber land,” and utăsûñ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, the third person perfect of the irregular verb, ga&mlprime;tûñskû&mlprime;, “I am growing up.”
Inâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;—Black-fox; the common red fox is tsu&mlprime;lă (in Muscogee, chula). Black-fox was principal chief of the Cherokee Nation in 1810. See page 86.
Iskagua—“Iakagua or Clear Sky, formerly Nenetooyah or the Bloody-Fellow.” The name appears thus in a document of 1791 as that of a Cherokee chief frequently mentioned about that period under the name of “the Bloody Fellow.” In one treaty it is given as “Eskaqua or Bloody Fellow.” Both forms and etymologies are doubtful, neither form seeming to have any reference either to “sky” (gălûñ&mlprime;lăh&ibreve;) or “blood” (gi&mlprime;ga). The first may be intended for Ik-e&mlprime;gwa, “Great-day.” See page 69.
Istanare—see U&okina;stăna&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
I&okina;sû&mlprime;nigû—an important Cherokee settlement, commonly known to the whites as Seneca, formerly on Keowee river, about the mouth of Conneross creek, in Oconee county, South Carolina. Hopewell, the country seat of General Pickens, where the famous treaty was made, was near it on the east side of the river. The word cannot be translated, but has no connection with the tribal name, Seneca.
Itaba—see I&mlprime;tăwă&mlprime;.
Ităgû&mlprime;năh&ibreve;—the Cherokee name of John Ax.
I&mlprime;tăwă&mlprime;—The name of one or more Cherokee settlements. One, which existed until the Removal in 1838, was upon Etowah river, about the present Hightower, in Forsyth county Georgia. Another may have been on Hightower creek of
Hiwassee river in Towns county, Georgia. The name, commonly written Etowah and corrupted to Hightower, cannot be translated and seems not to be of Cherokee origin. A town called Itaba, Ytaua or Ytava in the De Soto chronicles existed in 1540 among the Creeks, apparently on Alabama river.
Itsă&mlprime;t&ibreve;—commonly spelled Echota, Chota, Chote, Choquata (misprint), etc; a name occurring in several places in the old Cherokee country: the meaning is lost. The most important settlement of this name, frequently distinguished as Great Echota, was on the south side of Little Tennessee river a short distance below Citico creek in Monroe county, Tennessee. It was the ancient capital and sacred “peace town” of the Nation. Little Echota was on Sautee (i.e., Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;) creek, a head stream of the Chattahoochee, west of Clarkesville, Georgia. New Echota, the capital of the Nation for some years before the Removal, was established at a spot originally known as Gănsa&mlprime;g&ibreve; (q.v.) at the junction of the Oostanaula and Conasauga rivers, in Gordon county, Georgia. It was sometimes called Newtown. The old Macedonia mission on Soco creek, of the North Carolina reservation, is also known as Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve; to the Cherokee, as was also the great Nacoochee mound. See Nagu&okina;ts&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Itse&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“New green place” or “Place of fresh green,” from itse&mlprime;h&ibreve;, “green or unripe vegetation,” and y&ibreve;, the locative; applied more particularly to a tract of ground made green by fresh-springing vegetation, after having been cleared of timber or burned over. A name occurring in several places in the old Cherokee country, variously written Echia, Echoee, Etchowee, and sometimes also falsely rendered “Brasstown,” from a confusion of Itse&mlprime;y&ibreve; with ûñtsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime;, “brass.” One settlement of this name was upon Brasstown creek of Tugaloo river, in Oconee county, South Carolina; another was on Little Tennessee river near the present Franklin, Macon county, North Carolina, and probably about the junction of Cartoogaja (Gatug-itse&mlprime;y&ibreve;) creek; a third, known to the whites as Brasstown, was on upper Brasstown creek of Hiwassee river, in Towns county, Georgia. In Cherokee as in most other Indian languages no clear distinction is made between green and blue (sa&okina;ka&mlprime;nige&mlprime;&ibreve;).
i&mlprime;ya—pumpkin.
iya&mlprime;-iyu&mlprime;st&ibreve;—“like a pumpkin,” from iya and iyu&mlprime;st&ibreve;, like.
iya&mlprime;-tăwi&mlprime;skage—“of pumpkin smoothness,” from i&mlprime;ya, pumpkin, and tăwi&mlprime;skage, smooth.
Jackson—see Tsek&mlprime;s&ibreve;n&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Jessan—see Ts&ebreve;sa&mlprime;n&ibreve;.
Jesse Reid—see Ts&ebreve;&mlprime;s&ibreve;-Ska&mlprime;ts&ibreve;.
Joanna bald—see Diyâ&mlprime;hăli&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Joara, Juada—see Ani&mlprime;-Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
John—see Tsa&mlprime;n&ibreve;.
John Ax—see Ităgû&mlprime;năh&ibreve;.
Jolly, John—see Ahu&mlprime;lude&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Junaluska—see Tsunu&mlprime;lăhûñ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Jutaculla—see Tsul&okina;kălû&mlprime;.
kâ&mlprime;gû&mlprime;—crow; the name is an onomatope.
Kâgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Crow place,” from kâ&mlprime;gû&mlprime;, crow and y&ibreve;, locative. See number 63.
ka&mlprime;&ibreve;—grease, oil.
Kala&mlprime;ăsûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where he fell off,” from ts&ibreve;la&mlprime;ăskû&mlprime;, “I am falling off,” and y&ibreve;, locative. A cliff near Cold Spring knob, in Swain county, North Carolina.
Kâ&mlprime;lahû&mlprime;—“All-bones,” from kâ&mlprime;lû, bone. A former chief of the East Cherokee, also known in the tribe as Sawănu&mlprime;g&ibreve; (Shawano), and to the whites as Sawnook or Flying-squirrel.
Kâ&mlprime;lănû—“The Raven”; the name was used as a war title in the tribe and appears in the old documents as Corani (Lower dialect, Kâ&mlprime;rănû) Colanneh, Colona, etc. It is the Cherokee name for General Samuel Houston or for any person named Houston.
Kâ&mlprime;lănû Ahyeli&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—the Raven Mocker. See number 120.
Kâ&mlprime;lănûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Raven place,” from kâ&mlprime;lănû, raven, and y&ibreve;, the locative. The proper name of Big-cove settlement upon the East Cherokee reservation, Swain county, North Carolina, sometimes also called Raventown.
kalâs&mlprime;-gûnăhi&mlprime;ta—“long-hams” (gûnăhi&mlprime;ta), “long”); a variety of bear. See number 15.
Kâl-detsi&mlprime;yûñy&ibreve;—“Where the bones are,” from kâ&mlprime;lû, bone, and detsi&mlprime;yûñy&ibreve;, “where (y&ibreve;) they (de—plural prefix) are lying.” A spot near the junction of East Buffalo creek with Cheowa river, in Graham county, North Carolina. See number 122.
kăma&mlprime;ma—butterfly.
kăma&mlprime;ma u&mlprime;tanû—elephant; literally “great butterfly,” from the resemblance of the trunk and ears to the butterfly's proboscis and wings. See number 15.
kanahe&mlprime;na—a sour corn gruel, much in use among the Cherokee and other southern tribes; the tamfuli or “Tom Fuller” of the Creeks.
kănăne&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—spider; also, from a fancied resemblance in appearance, a watch or clock; kănăne&mlprime;sk&ibreve; amăy&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;, the water spider.
Kăna&mlprime;sta, Kănastûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—a traditional Cherokee settlement formerly on the headwaters of the French Broad river near the present Brevard, in Transylvania county, North Carolina. The meaning of the name is lost. A settlement called Cannostee or Cannastion is mentioned as existing on Hiwassee river in 1776. See number 82 and notes.
kanâ&mlprime;talu&mlprime;h&ibreve;—hominy cooked with walnut kernels.
Kana&mlprime;t&ibreve;— “Lucky Hunter”; a masculine name, sometimes abbreviated Kanat&mlprime;. The word can not be analyzed, but is used as a third person habitual verbal form to mean “he is lucky, or successful, in hunting”; the opposite is u&okina;kwa&mlprime;legû, “unlucky, or unsuccessful, in hunting.” See number 3.
kanegwâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;—the water-moccasin snake.
Kănu&mlprime;ga—also written Canuga; a Lower Cherokee settlement, apparently on the waters of Keowee river in South Carolina, destroyed in 1761; also a traditional settlement on Pigeon river, probably near the present Waynesville, in Haywood county, North Carolina. See number 81 and notes. The name signifies “a scratcher,” a sort of bone-toothed comb with which ball-players are scratched upon their naked skin preliminary to applying the conjured medicine; de&mlprime;tsinuga&mlprime;skû, “I am scratching it.”
kănugû&mlprime;&okina;lă (abbreviated nugû&mlprime;&okina;la)—“scratcher,” a generic term for the blackberry, raspberry, and other brier bushes. Cf. Kănu&mlprime;ga.
Kănu&mlprime;gû&okina;lây&ibreve;, or Kănu&mlprime;gû&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Brier place,” from kănu&mlprime;gû&mlprime;&okina;lâ, brier (cf. Kănu&mlprime;ga); a Cherokee settlement formerly on Nantahala river, about the mouth of Briertown creek, in Macon county, North Carolina.
kănûñ&mlprime;năwû&mlprime;—pipe.
Kâsdu&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Ashes place,” from kâsdu, ashes, and y&ibreve;, the locative. A modern Cherokee name for the town of Asheville, in Buncombe county, North Carolina. The ancient name for the same site is Unta&mlprime;kiyasti&mlprime;y&ibreve;, q.v.
Katâl&mlprime;stă—an East Cherokee woman potter, the daughter of the chief Yânăgûñ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;. The name conveys the idea of lending, from tsiyâtâl&mlprime;stă, “I lend it”; agatâl&mlprime;stă, “it is lent to him.”
Kăwân&mlprime;-urâ&mlprime;sûny&ibreve; (abbreviated Kăwân&mlprime;-urâ&mlprime;sûñ in the Lower dialect)—“Where the duck fell” from kăwâ&mlprime;nă, duck, urâ&mlprime;să (ulâ&mlprime;să), “it fell,” and y&ibreve;, locative. A
point on Conneross creek (from Kăwân&mlprime;-urâ&mlprime;sûñ), near Seneca, in Oconee county, South Carolina. See number 123.
Kawi&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Kawi&mlprime;)—a former important Cherokee settlement, commonly known as Cowee, about the mouth of Cowee creek of Little Tennessee river, some 10 miles below Franklin, in Macon county, North Carolina. The name may possibly be a contraction of Ani&mlprime;-Kawi&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Place of the Deer clan.”
Keeowhee—see Keowee.
Kenesaw—see Gănsâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Keowee—the name of two or more former Cherokee settlements. One, sometimes distinguished as “Old Keowee,” the principal of the Lower Cherokee towns, was on the river of the same name, near the present Fort George, in Oconee county, South Carolina. Another, distinguished as New Keowee, was on the headwaters of Twelve-mile creek, in Pickens county, South Carolina. According to Wafford the correct form is Kuwâhi&mlprime;y&ibreve;, abbreviated Kuwâhi&mlprime;, “Mulberry-grove place”; says Wafford, “The whites murdered the name, as they always do.” Cf. Kuwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Ke&mlprime;s&ibreve;-ka&mlprime;gămû—a woman's name, a Cherokee corruption of Cassie Cockram; ka&mlprime;gămû is also the Cherokee corruption for “cucumber.”
Ketoowah—see K&ibreve;tu&mlprime;hwă.
Kittuwa—see K&ibreve;tu&mlprime;hwă.
K&ibreve;tu&mlprime;hwă—An important ancient Cherokee settlement formerly upon Tuckasegee river, and extending from above the junction of Oconaluftee down nearly to the present Bryson City, in Swain county, North Carolina. The name, which appears also as Kettooah, Kittoa, Kittowa, etc., has lost its meaning. The people of this and the subordinate settlements on the waters of the Tuckasegee were known as Ani&mlprime;-K&ibreve;tu&mlprime;hwag&ibreve; and the name was frequently extended to include the whole tribe. For this reason it was adopted in later times as the name of the Cherokee secret organization, commonly known to the whites as the Ketoowah society, pledged to the defense of Cherokee autonomy. See also historical notes 1 and 47.
kiyu&okina;ga—ground-squirrel; te&mlprime;wa, flying squirrel; sălâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;, gray squirrel.
Klausuna—see Tlanusi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Knoxville—see Kuwandâ&mlprime;tâ&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
kû!—an introductory exclamation, to fix attention, about equivalent to “Now!”
kukû&mlprime;—“cymling”; also the “jigger weed,” or “pleurisy root” (Asclepias tuberosa). Coco creek of Hiwassee river, and Coker postoffice, in Monroe county Tennessee, derive their name from this word.
Kûlsetsi&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Kûlse&mlprime;tsi)—“Honey-locust place,” from kûlse&mlprime;ts&ibreve;, honey-locust (Gleditschia) and y&ibreve; locative; as the same word, kûlse&mlprime;ts&ibreve;, is also used for “sugar,” the local name has commonly been rendered Sugartown by the traders. The name of several former settlement places in the old Cherokee country. One was upon Keowee river, near the present Fall creek, in Oconee county, South Carolina; another was on Sugartown or Cullasagee (Kûlse&mlprime;tsi) creek, near the present Franklin, in Macon county, North Carolina; a third was on Sugartown creek, near the present Morganton, in Fannin county, Georgia.
Kunnesee—see Tsi&mlprime;yu-gûnsi&mlprime;n&ibreve;.
Kûnstûtsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Sassafras place,” from kûnstû&mlprime;ts&ibreve;, sassafras, and y&ibreve;, locative. A gap in the Great Smoky range, about the head of Noland creek, on the line between North Carolina and Sevier county, Tennessee.
kûnu&mlprime;nŭ (abbreviated kûnun&mlprime;)—the bullfrog; the name is probably an onomatope; the common green frog is walâ&mlprime;s&ibreve; and there are also names for several other varieties of frogs and toads.
Kusă&mlprime;—Coosa creek, an upper tributary of Nottely river, near Blairsville, Union county, Georgia. The change of accent from Ku&mlprime;să (Creek, see Ani&mlprime;-Ku&mlprime;sa) makes it locative. See page 383.
Ku&mlprime;să-nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Creek trail,” from Ku&mlprime;să, Creek Indian, and nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, path, trail; cf. Suwâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;-nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;. A former important Cherokee settlement, including also a number of Creeks and Shawano, where the trail from the Ohio region to the Creek country crossed Tennessee river, at the present Guntersville, in Marshall county, Alabama. It was known to the traders as Creek-path, and later as Gunter's landing, from a Cherokee mixed-blood named Gunter.
Ku&mlprime;săweti&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Ku&mlprime;săweti&mlprime;)—“Old Creek place,” from Ku&mlprime;să, a Creek Indian (plural Ani&mlprime;-Ku&mlprime;sa), uwe&mlprime;t&ibreve;, old, and y&ibreve;, locative. Coosawatee, an important Cherokee settlement formerly on the lower part of Coosawatee river, in Gordon county, Georgia. In one document the name appears, by error, Tensawattee. See page 382.
Kuwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Mulberry place,” from ku&mlprime;wă, mulberry tree, and h&ibreve;, locative; Clingman's dome, about the head of Deep creek, on the Great Smoky range, between Swain county, North Carolina, and Sevier county, Tennessee. See also Keowee.
Kuwandâ&mlprime;ta&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Kuwandâ&mlprime;ta&okina;lûñ)—“Mulberry grove,” from ku&mlprime;wă, mulberry; the Cherokee name for the present site of Knoxville, in Knox county, Tennessee.
Kwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;, Kwalûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—Qualla or Quallatown, the former agency for the East Cherokee and now a postoffice station, just outside the reservation, on a branch of Soco creek, in Jackson county, North Carolina. It is the Cherokee form for “Polly,” and the station was so called from an old woman of that name who formerly lived near by; Kwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;, “Polly,” Kwalûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Polly's place.” The reservation is locally known as the Qualla boundary.
kwandăya&mlprime;hû—see da&mlprime;l&ibreve;kstă&mlprime;.
lâ&mlprime;lû—the jar-fly (Cicada auletes). See number 59.
Little Carpenter, Little Cornplanter—see Ătă&mlprime;-gûl&okina;kălû.
Lloyd—see Da&mlprime;si&okina;giya&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Long-hair—a Cherokee chief living with his band in Ohio in 1795. See page 79. The literal Cherokee translation of “Long-hair” is Gitlû&mlprime;-gûnăhi&mlprime;ta, but it is not certain that the English name is a correct rendering of the Indian form. Cf. Ani&mlprime;-Gilâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Long island—see Ămăye&okina;l&ibreve;-gûnăhi&mlprime;ta.
Lookout Mountain town—see Danda&mlprime;gănû&mlprime;.
Lowrey, Major George—see Agi&okina;l&ibreve;.
Mayes, J. B.—see Tsâ&mlprime;wă Gak&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Memphis—see Tsudâ&mlprime;tălesûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Mialaquo—see Ămăye&okina;l-e&mlprime;gwa.
Morgan—see Âganstâ&mlprime;ta.
Moses—see Wă&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
Moytoy—a Cherokee chief recognized by the English as “emperor” in 1730. Both the correct form and the meaning of the name are uncertain; the name occurs again as Moyatoy in a document of 1792; a boy upon the East Cherokee reservation a few years ago bore the name of Ma&mlprime;tay&ibreve;&mlprime;, for which no meaning can be given.
Muscle shoals—see Dăgû&mlprime;nâh&ibreve;.
Nacoochee—see Na&mlprime;gu&okina;ts&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Na&mlprime;dû&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;—known to the whites as Nottely. A former Cherokee settlement on Nottely river, close to the Georgia line, in Cherokee county, North Carolina. The name cannot be translated and has no connection with na&okina;tû&okina;l&ibreve;, “spicewood.”
Nagu&okina;ts&ibreve;&mlprime;—a former important settlement about the junction of Soquee and Santee rivers, in Nacoochee valley, at the head of Chattahoochee river, in Habersham county, Georgia. The meaning of the word is lost and it is doubtful if it be of
Cherokee origin. It may have some connection with the name of the Uchee Indians. The great mound farther up Sautee river, in White county, was known to the Cherokee as Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;, q.v.
năkw&ibreve;s&ibreve;&mlprime; (abbreviated năkw&okina;s&ibreve;)—star; also the meadow lark.
năkw&ibreve;s&ibreve;&mlprime;usdi&mlprime;—“little star”; the puff ball fungus (Lycoperdon?).
Nâ&mlprime;nă-tlu&okina;gûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Nâ&mlprime;nă-tlu&okina;gûñ&mlprime;, or Nâ&mlprime;nă-tsu&okina;gûñ&mlprime;)—“Spruce-tree place,” from nâ&mlprime;nă, spruce, tlu&okina;gûñ&mlprime;&ibreve; or tsu&okina;gûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, a tree (standing) and y&ibreve;, locative. 1. A traditional ancient Cherokee settlement on the site of Jonesboro, Washington county, Tennessee. The name of Nolichucky river is probably a corruption of the same word. 2. Nână-tsu&okina;gûñ, a place on Nottely river, close to its junction with Hiwassee, in Cherokee county, North Carolina.
Nanehi—see Nûñn&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Nantahala—see Nûñdăye&mlprime;&okina;l&ibreve;.
Nashville—see Dagû&mlprime;năwe&mlprime;lâh&ibreve;.
Natchez—see Ani&mlprime;-Na&okina;ts&ibreve;.
Na&okina;ts-asûñ&mlprime;tlûñy&ibreve; (abbreviated Na&okina;ts-asûñ&mlprime;tlûñ)—“Pine-footlog place,” from na&okina;ts&ibreve;, pine, asûñ&mlprime;tl&ibreve; or asûñtlûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, footlog, bridge, and y&ibreve;, locative. A former Cherokee settlement, commonly known as Pinelog, on the creek of the same name, in Bartow county, Georgia.
na&okina;ts&ibreve;—pine.
na&mlprime;ts&ibreve;kû&mlprime;—“I eat it” (ts&ibreve;&mlprime;kiû&mlprime;, “I am eating”).
na&okina;tû&okina;l&ibreve;—spicewood (Lindera benzoin).
Nay&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;—see Nûñn&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Nayunuwi—see Nûñyunu&mlprime;w&ibreve;.
nehanduyanû&mlprime;—a song form for nehadu&mlprime;yanû&mlprime;, an irregular verbal form denoting “conceived in the womb.” See number 75.
Nellawgitehi—given as the name of a Lower Cherokee chief in 1684. See page 31. The correct form and meaning are both uncertain, but the final part seems to be the common suffix dih&ibreve;&mlprime;—, “killer,” Cf. Ta&mlprime;gwădih&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Nenetooyah—see Iskagua.
Nequassee—see N&ibreve;&mlprime;kwăs&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Nettecawaw—see gatayû&mlprime;st&ibreve;.
Nettle-carrier—see Tâle&mlprime;danigi&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
New Echota, Newtown—see Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;.
Nickajack—see N&ibreve;kutse&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Nicotani—see Ani&mlprime;-Kuta&mlprime;n&ibreve;.
N&ibreve;kwăs&ibreve;&mlprime; (or Nikw&mlapos;s&ibreve;&mlprime;)—an important ancient settlement on Little Tennessee river, where now is the town of Franklin, in Macon county, North Carolina. A large mound marks the site of the townhouse. The name appears in old documents as Nequassee, Nucassee, etc. Its meaning is lost.
N&ibreve;kutse&mlprime;g&ibreve; (also Nûkătse&mlprime;g&ibreve;, Nikwătse&mlprime;g&ibreve;, or abbreviated N&ibreve;kutseg&mlprime;)—Nickajack, an important Cherokee settlement about 1790 on the south bank of Tennessee river at the entrance of Nickajack creek, in Marion county, Tennessee. One of the five Chickamauga towns (see Ts&ibreve;kăma&mlprime;g&ibreve;). The meaning of the word is lost and it is probably not of Cherokee origin, although it occurs also in the tribe as a man's name. In the corrupted form of “Nigger Jack,” it occurs also as the name of a creek of Cullasagee river above Franklin, in Macon county, North Carolina.
Nilaque—see Ămăye&okina;l-e&mlprime;gwă.
Nolichucky—see Nâ&mlprime;nătlu&okina;gûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Notchy—a creek entering Tellico river, in Monroe county, Tennessee. The name evidently refers to Natchez Indian refugees, who formerly lived in the vicinity (see Ani&mlprime;-Na&okina;ts&ibreve;).
Nottely—see Na&mlprime;dû&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;.
nû—used as a suffix to denote “and,” or “also”; û&mlprime;l&ebreve;-&okina;nû, “and also”; na&mlprime;ski&okina;-nû&mlprime;, “and that,” “that also.”
Nucassee—see N&ibreve;kwăs&ibreve;&mlprime;.
nu&mlprime;dûñnelû&mlprime;—he did so and so; an irregular form apparently connected with the archaic forms adûñni&mlprime;ga, “it has just become so,” and udûñnû&mlprime;, “it is matured, or finished.” See number 118.
nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime;—the sun or moon, distinguished as nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime; ig&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;, “nûñ&mlprime;dã&mlprime; dwelling in the day,” and nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime; sûñnâ&mlprime;y&ebreve;h&ibreve;, “nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime; dwelling in the night.” In the sacred formulas the moon is sometimes called Ge&okina;yăgu&mlprime;ga, q.v., or Su&mlprime;tălidih&ibreve;&mlprime;, “Six-killer,” names apparently founded upon myths now lost.
nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime;-dika&okina;n&ibreve;—a rare bird formerly seen occasionally in the old Cherokee country, possibly the little blue heron (Floridus cerulea). The name seems to mean “it looks at the sun,” i.e., “sun-gazer,” from nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime;, sun, and da&mlprime;ka&okina;nă&mlprime; or detsi&mlprime;ka&okina;nă, “I am looking at it.” See number 35.
Nûñ&mlprime;dâgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, Nûñdâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—the Sun land, or east; from nûñdă&mlprime;, sun, and y&ibreve;, locative. Used in the sacred formulas instead of di&mlprime;gălûñgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “where it rises,” the common word.
Nûñ&mlprime;dăye&okina;l&ibreve;—“Middle (i.e. Noonday) sun,” from nûñdă&mlprime;, sun and aye&okina;l&ibreve;, middle; a former Cherokee settlement on Nantahala river, near the present Jarrett station, in Macon county, North Carolina, so called from the high cliffs which shut out the view of the sun until nearly noon. The name appears also as Nantahala, Nantiyallee, Nuntialla, etc. It appears to have been applied properly only to the point on the river where the cliffs are most perpendicular, while the settlement itself was known as Kanu&mlprime;gû&okina;lâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Briertown,” q.v. See number 122.
Nugătsa&mlprime;n&ibreve;—a ridge sloping down to Oconaluftee river, below Cherokee, in Swain county, North Carolina. The word is an archaic form denoting a high ridge with a long gradual slope. See number 122.
nûñ&mlprime;g&ibreve;&mlprime;—four. See h&ibreve;&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
nugû&okina;la—see kănugû&okina;la.
Nuhnayie—see Nûñn&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
nu&mlprime;nă—potato; the name was originally applied to the wild “pig potato” (Phaseolus), now distinguished as nu&mlprime;nă igât&ebreve;h&ibreve;, “swamp-dwelling potato.”
Nûndăwe&mlprime;g&ibreve;—see Ani&mlprime;-Nûndăwe&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve; (abbreviated nûñnâ)—a path, trail or road.
Nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;-dih&ibreve;&mlprime; (abbreviated Nûñ&mlprime;nâ-dih&ibreve;&mlprime;)—“Path-killer,” literally, “He kills (habitually) in the path,” from nûñ&mlprime;nâh&ibreve;, path, and ahih&ibreve;, “he kills” (habitually); “I am killing,” tsi&mlprime;ihû&mlprime;. A principal chief, about the year 1813. Major John Ridge was originally known by the same name, but afterward took the name, Gûnûñ&mlprime;da&okina;le&mlprime;g&ibreve;, “One who follows the ridge,” which the whites made simply Ridge.
Nûnnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;-tsune&mlprime;ga (abbreviated) Nûñnâ-tsune&mlprime;ga—“White-path,” from nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, path, and tsune&mlprime;ga, plural of une&mlprime;ga, white; the form is in the plural, as is common in Indian names, and has probably a symbolic reference to the “white” or peaceful paths spoken of in the opening invocation at the Green corn dance. A noted chief who led the conservative party about 1828. See pages 113, 132.
Nûñn&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve; (also Gûñn&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;; singular Nay&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;)—a race of invisible spirit people. The name is derived from the verb &ebreve;&mlprime;hû&mlprime;, “I dwell, I live,” &ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;&mlprime;, “I dwell habitually,” and may be rendered “dwellers anywhere,” or “those who live anywhere,” but implies having always been there, i.e., “Immortals.” It has been spelled Nanehi and Nuhnayie by different writers. The singular form Nay&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve; occurs also as a personal name, about equivalent to Edă&mlprime;h&ibreve;, “One who goes about.” See number 78.
nuniyu&mlprime;st&ibreve;—“potato-like,” from nu&mlprime;nă, potato, and iyu&mlprime;st&ibreve;, like. A flowering vine with tuberous root somewhat resembling the potato. See number 126.
nûñyû&mlprime;—rock, stone. Cf. nâyŭ, sand
Nûñyû&mlprime;-gûñwani&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—“Rock that talks,” from nûñyû&mlprime;, rock, and tsiwa&mlprime;nihû, “I am talking.” A rock from which Talking-rock creek of Coosawatee river in Georgia derives its name. See number 125.
Nûñ&mlprime;yunu&mlprime;w&ibreve;—contracted from Nûñyû-unu&mlprime;w&ibreve;. “Stone-clad,” from nûñyû, rock, and agwănu&mlprime;wû, “I am clothed or covered.” A mythic monster, invulnerable by reason of his stony skin. See number 67. The name is also applied sometimes to the stinging ant, dasûñtâl&ibreve; atatsûñsk&ibreve;, q.v. It has also been spelled Nayunuwi.
Nûñyû&mlprime;-tlu&okina;gûñ&ibreve; (or Nûñyû-tsu&okina;gûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;)—“Tree rock.” A notable rock on Hiwassee river, just within the North Carolina line. See number 66 and notes.
Nûñyû&mlprime;-tăwi&mlprime;skă—“Slick rock,” from nûñyû&mlprime;, rock, and tăwiskă, smooth, slick; the form remains unchanged for the locative. 1. Slick-rock creek, entering Little Tennessee river just within the west line of Graham county, North Carolina. 2. A place at the extreme head of Brasstown creek of Hiwassee river, in Towns county, Georgia.
Ocoee—see Uwagâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Oconaluftee—see Egwânul&okina;t&ibreve;.
Oconee—see Ukwû&mlprime;nû.
Oconostota—see Âganstâ&mlprime;ta.
Old Tassel—see Utsi&mlprime;dsătă&mlprime;.
Ooltewah—see Ultiwâ&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Oolunsade—see Ulûñsû&mlprime;t&ibreve;.
Oostanaula—see U stăna&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
Oostinaleh—see U stăna&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
Oothcaloga—see Uy&okina;gilâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Otacite, Otassite—see Outacity.
Otari, Otariyatiqui—mentioned as a place, apparently on the Cherokee frontier, visited by Pardo in 1567. Otari seems to be the Cherokee âtăr&ibreve; or âtăl&ibreve;, mountain, but the rest of the word is doubtful. See page 28.
Ottare—see â&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;.
Owasta—given as the name of a Cherokee chief in 1684; the form cannot be identified. See page 31.
Ougillogy—see Uy&okina;gilâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Outacity—given in documents as the name or title of a prominent Cherokee chief about 1720. It appears also as Otacite, Otassite, Outassatah, Wootassite and Wrosetasatow (!), but the form cannot be identified, although it seems to contain the personal name suffix dih&ibreve;&mlprime;, “killer.” Timberlake says (page 71): “There are some other honorary titles among them, conferred in reward of great actions; the first of which is Outacity or Man-killer, and the second Colona or the Raven.”
Outassatah—see Outacity.
Owassa—see Ayuhwa&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
Paint-town—see Ani&mlprime;-Wâ&mlprime;dih&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Path-killer—see Nûñnâ&mlprime;hi-dih&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Phœnix, Cherokee—see Tsule&mlprime;hisanûñ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Pigeon River—see Wây&ibreve;.
Pine Indians—see Ani&mlprime;-Na&okina;ts&ibreve;.
Pinelog—see Na&okina;ts-asûñ&mlprime;tlûñy&ibreve;.
Qualatchee—a former Cherokee settlement on the headwaters of the Chattahoochee river in Georgia; another of the same name was upon the waters of Keowee river in South Carolina. The correct form is unknown.
Qualla—see Kwal&ibreve;.
Quaxule—see Guaxule.
Quinahaqui—a place, possibly in the Cherokee country, visited by Pardo in 1567. The form cannot be identified. See page 28.
Quoneashee—see Tlanusi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Rattlesnake springs—see Utsanătiy&ibreve;.
Rattling-gourd—see Găns&ebreve;&okina;t&ibreve;.
Raventown—see Kâlănûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Red Clay—see Elăwâ&mlprime;diy&ibreve;.
Reid, Jesse—see Tse&mlprime;si-Ska&mlprime;ts&ibreve;.
Ridge, Major John—see Nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;-dih&ibreve;.
Ross, John—see Gu&mlprime;wisguw&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Ross' landing—see Tsatănu&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Saday&ibreve;&mlprime;—a feminine name, the proper name of the woman known to the whites as Annie Ax; it cannot be translated.
Sâgwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, or Sâgwûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“One place,” from sâ&mlprime;gwû, one, and h&ibreve; or y&ibreve;, locative. Soco creek of Oconaluftee river, on the East Cherokee reservation, in Jackson county, North Carolina. No satisfactory reason is given for the name, which has its parallel in Tsâskâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, “Thirty place,” a local name in Cherokee county, in the same state.
sâ&mlprime;gwăl&ibreve;&mlprime;, horse; from asâgwâlihû, a pack or burden, asâgwŭllû&mlprime;; “there is a pack on him.”
sâ&mlprime;gwăl&ibreve; d&ibreve;gû&mlprime;lanăhi&mlprime;ta—mule; literally “long eared horse,” from sâ&mlprime;gwăl&ibreve;, horse, and digû&mlprime;lanăhi&mlprime;ta, q.v.
Sâkwi&mlprime;y&ibreve; (or Suki&mlprime;y&ibreve;; abbreviated Sâkwi&mlprime; or Suki&mlprime;)—a former settlement on Soquee river, a head-stream of Chattahoochee, near Clarkesville, Habersham county, Georgia. Also written Saukee and Sookee. The name has lost its meaning.
sălâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;—squirrel; the common gray squirrel; other varieties are kiyu&okina;ga, the ground squirrel, and tewa, the flying squirrel.
