Sălâ&mlprime;l&ibreve; was also the name of an East Cherokee inventor who died a few years ago; Sălâ&mlprime;lăni&mlprime;ta, “Young-squirrels,” is a masculine personal name on the reservation.
săligu&mlprime;g&ibreve;—turtle, the common water turtle; soft-shell turtle, u&okina;lănă&mlprime;wă; land tortoise or terrapin, tûks&ibreve;&mlprime;.
sălikwâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—bear-grass (Eryngium); also the greensnake, on account of a fancied resemblance; the name of a former Cherokee settlement on Sallacoa creek of Coosawatee river, in Gordon county, Georgia.
Sa&mlprime;nigilâ&mlprime;g&ibreve; (abbreviated San&okina;gilâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;)—Whiteside mountain, a prominent peak of the Blue ridge, southeast from Franklin, Macon county, North Carolina. It is connected with the tradition of U&okina;tlûñ&mlprime;ta (see number 66 and notes).
Santeetla—the present map name of a creek joining Cheowa river in Graham county, North Carolina, and of a smaller tributary (Little Santeetla). The name is not recognized or understood by the Cherokee, who insist that it was given by the whites. Little Santeetla is known to the Cherokee as Tsunda&okina;nilti&mlprime;y&ibreve;, q.v.; the main Santeetla creek is commonly known as Nâgu&mlprime;h&ibreve; geyûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, “Sand-place stream,” from Nûyu&mlprime;hi&ibreve;, “Sand place” (nâyŭ, sand), a former settlement just above the junction of the two creeks.
Sara—see Ani&mlprime;-Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
sa&mlprime;sa&mlprime;—goose; an onomatope.
Sautee—see Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;.
Savannah—the popular name of this river is derived from that of the Shawano Indians, formerly living upon its middle course, and known to the Cherokee as Ani&mlprime;-Sawănu&mlprime;g&ibreve;, q.v., to the Creeks as Savanuka, and to some of the coast tribes
of Carolina as Savanna. In old documents the river is also called Isundiga, from I&okina;sû&mlprime;nigû or Seneca, q.v., an important former Cherokee settlement upon its upper waters. See number 99.
Sawănu&mlprime;g&ibreve;—“Shawano” (Indian); a masculine personal name upon the East Cherokee reservation and prominent in the history of the band. See An&ibreve;&mlprime;-Sawănu&mlprime;g&ibreve; and Kâ&mlprime;lahû&mlprime;.
Sawnook—see Kâ&mlprime;lahû&mlprime;.
Sehwate&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Hornet place,” from se&mlprime;hwatû, hornet, and y&ibreve;, locative. Cheowa Maximum and Swim bald, adjoining bald peaks at the head of Cheowa river, Graham county, North Carolina. See number 122.
selu—corn; sometimes called in the sacred formulas Agawe&mlprime;la, “The Old Woman.” See number 126.
sel-uts&ibreve;&mlprime; (for selu-uts&ibreve;&mlprime;)—“corn's mother,” from selu, corn and uts&ibreve;&mlprime;, his mother (ets&ibreve;&mlprime; or agits&ibreve;&mlprime;, my mother); the bead-corn or Job's-tears (Coix lacryma). See number 126.
Seneca—see Ani&mlprime;-Nûn&mlprime;dăwe&mlprime;g&ibreve; (Seneca tribe), and I&okina;sû&mlprime;nigû, (Seneca town).
Sequatchee—see S&ibreve;&mlprime;gwets&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Sequoya—see Sikwây&ibreve;.
S&ebreve;&okina;ts&ibreve;—a mound and traditional Cherokee settlement on the south side of Valley river, about three miles below Valleytown, in Cherokee county, North Carolina; the name has lost its meaning. See number 79. A settlement called Tăs&ebreve;&okina;ts&ibreve; (Tassetchie in some old documents) existed on the extreme head of Hiwassee river, in Towns county, Georgia.
Sevier—see Tsan&mlprime;-usdi&mlprime;.
Shoe-boots—see Da&mlprime;si&okina;giya&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Shooting creek—see Du&mlprime;stăya&okina;lûñy&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
S&ibreve;&mlprime;gwets&ibreve;&mlprime;—a traditional Cherokee settlement on the south bank of the French Broad river, not far from Knoxville, Knox county, Tennessee. Near by was the quarry from which it is said the stone for the white peace pipes was obtained. See number 111 and notes. Sequatchee, the name of the river below Chattanooga, in Tennessee, is probably a corruption of the same word.
s&ibreve;&mlprime;kwă—hog; originally the name of the opossum, now distinguished as s&ibreve;&mlprime;kwă utset&mlprime;st&ibreve;, q.v.
s&ibreve;&mlprime;kwă utset&mlprime;st&ibreve;—opossum: literally “grinning hog,” from s&ibreve;&mlprime;kwă, hog, and utset&mlprime;st&ibreve;, “he grins (habitually).” Cf. s&ibreve;kwă.
Sikwâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—a masculine name, commonly written Sequoya, made famous as that of the inventor of the Cherokee alphabet. See page 108. The name, which can not be translated, is still in use upon the East Cherokee reservation.
Sikwi&mlprime;ă—a masculine name, the Cherokee corruption for Sevier. See also Tsan-usdi&mlprime;.
sinnawah—see tlă&mlprime;nuwă.
S&ibreve;&mlprime;tikû&mlprime; (or sû&mlprime;tăgû&mlprime;, in dialectic form)—a former Cherokee settlement on Little Tennessee river at the entrance of Citico creek, in Monroe county, Tennessee. The name, which can not be translated, is commonly spelled Citico, but appears also as Sattiquo, Settico, Settacoo, Sette, Sittiquo, etc.
siyu&mlprime;—see â&mlprime;siyu&mlprime;.
sk&ibreve;ntâ&mlprime;—for sk&ibreve;n&mlprime;tâgû&mlprime;, understood to mean “put a new tooth into my jaw.” The word can not be analyzed, but is derived from găntkă&mlprime; (ganta&okina;gă in a dialectic form) a tooth in place; a tooth detached is kăyu&okina;gă. See number 15.
Skwan&mlprime;-digû&okina;gûñ&mlprime;yî (for Askwan&mlprime;-digû&okina;gûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;)—“Where the Spaniard is in the water [or other liquid]”. A place on Upper Soco creek, on the reservation in Jackson county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Slick rock—see Nûñyû&mlprime;-tăwi&mlprime;skă.
Smith, N. J.—see Tsalădih&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Snowbird—see Tuti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Soco creek—see Sâgwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Soco gap—see Ăhălu&mlprime;na.
Soquee—see Sâkwi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Spray, H. W.—see W&ibreve;ls&ibreve;n&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Spring-Frog—see Du&mlprime;stu&mlprime;.
Standing Indian—see Yûñw&ibreve;-tsulenûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Stand Watie—see De&mlprime;gatâgă.
Stekoa—see Stikâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
ste&mlprime;tsi—your daughter; literally, your offspring; agwe&mlprime;ts&ibreve;, “my offspring”; uwe&mlprime;ts&ibreve;, “his offspring”; to distinguish sex it is necessary to add asga&mlprime;ya, “man” or age&mlprime;hya, “woman.”
Stikâ&mlprime;y&ibreve; (variously spelled Stecoe, Steecoy, Stekoah, Stickoey, etc.)—the name of several former Cherokee settlements: 1. On Sticoa creek, near Clayton, Rabun county, Georgia; 2. on Tuckasegee river at the old Thomas homestead just above the present Whittier, in Swain county, North Carolina; 3. on Stekoa creek of Little Tennessee river, a few miles below the junction of Nantahala, in Graham county, North Carolina. The word has lost its meaning.
Stringfield—see Tlâge&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
stugi&mlprime;st&ibreve;, stui&mlprime;st&ibreve;—a key; see page 187 and under Astu&mlprime;gatâ&mlprime;ga.
Suck, The—see Ûñ&mlprime;tiguh&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Sugartown—see Kûlse&mlprime;tsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
sû&mlprime;năwă&mlprime;—see tlă&mlprime;nuwă.
sûn&ebreve;stlâ&mlprime;tă—“split noses”; see tsunû&okina;liyû&mlprime; sûn&ebreve;stlâ&mlprime;tă.
sûñg&ibreve;—mink; also onion; the name seems to refer to a smell; the various mints are called generically, gaw&okina;sûñ&mlprime;g&ibreve;. See number 29.
Suki&mlprime;y&ibreve;—another form of Sâkwi&mlprime;y&ibreve;, q.v.
su&mlprime;l&ibreve;&mlprime;—buzzard; the Creek name is the same.
Sun land—see Nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
su&mlprime;-să&mlprime;-sai&mlprime;—an unmeaning song refrain. See number 66.
su&mlprime;tălidih&ibreve;&mlprime;—see nûñ&mlprime;dă&mlprime;.
Suwa&mlprime;li—see Ani&mlprime;-Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;-nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve; (abbreviated Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;-nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;)—“Suwali trail,” the proper name for the gap at the head of Swannanoa (from Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;-Nûñ&mlprime;nâ) river, east of Asheville, in Buncombe county, North Carolina. Cf. Ku&mlprime;să-nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;. See pages 194 and 379, also Ani&mlprime;-Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
Suwa&okina;n&ibreve;—a former Cherokee settlement on Chattahoochee river, about the present Suwanee, in Gwinnett county, Georgia. The name has no meaning in the Cherokee language and is said to be of Creek origin. See page 382.
Suye&mlprime;ta—“The Chosen One,” from asuye&mlprime;ta, “he is chosen,” gasu&mlprime;yeû, “I am choosing”; the same form, suye&mlprime;ta, could also mean mixed, from gasu&mlprime;yăhû, “I am mixing it.” A masculine name, at present borne by a prominent ex-chief and informant upon the East Cherokee reservation.
Swannanoa—see Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;-nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Swim bald—see Sehwate&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Swimmer—see A&okina;yûñ&mlprime;in&ibreve;.
tadeyâ&mlprime;statakûh&ibreve;&mlprime;—“we shall see each other.” See number 75.
Tae-keo-ge—see Ta&okina;ski&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
ta&mlprime;gû—the June-bug (Allorhina nitida), also called tu&mlprime;ya-d&ibreve;skalaw&mlapos;sti&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, “one who keeps fire under the beans.” See number 59.
Ta&mlprime;gwa—see Ani&mlprime;ta&mlprime;gwa.
Ta&mlprime;gwădih&ibreve;&mlprime; (abbreviated Ta&mlprime;gwădi&mlprime;)—“Catawba-killer,” from Ata&mlprime;gwa or Ta&mlprime;gwa, Catawba Indian, and dihih&ibreve;, “he kills them” (habitually) from tsi&mlprime;ihû&mlprime;,
“I kill.” An old masculine personal name, still in use upon the East Cherokee reservation. It was the proper name of the chief known to the whites about 1790 as “The Glass,” from a confusion of this name with adak&ebreve;&mlprime;&okina;t&ibreve;, glass, or mirror.
Tagwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Catawba place,” from Ata&mlprime;gwa or Ta&mlprime;gwa, Catawba Indian, and h&ibreve;, locative. A name occurring in several places in the old Cherokee country. A settlement of this name, known to the whites as Toccoa, was upon Toccoa creek, east of Clarkesville, in Habersham county, Georgia; another was upon Toccoa or Ocoee river, about the present Toccoa, in Fannin county, Georgia; a third may have been on Persimmon creek, which is known to the Cherokee as Tagwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, and enters Hiwassee river some distance below Murphy, in Cherokee county, North Carolina.
Tahkeyostee—see Unta&mlprime;kiyasti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Tahlequah—see Tălikwă&mlprime;.
Tahchee—see Tăts&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Takatoka—see De&mlprime;gătâ&mlprime;gă.
tă&mlprime;lădŭ&mlprime; (abbreviated tăldŭ&mlprime;)—twelve, from tă&mlprime;l&ibreve;, two. Cf. tăla&mlprime;tŭ, cricket.
Tă&okina;las&ibreve;&mlprime;—a former Cherokee settlement on Little Tennessee river, about Talassee ford, in Blount county, Tennessee. The name has lost its meaning.
Talassee—see Tă&okina;las&ibreve;&mlprime;.
tăla&mlprime;tŭ—cricket; sometimes also called dita&mlprime;staye&mlprime;sk&ibreve; (q.v.), “the barber.” Cf. tă&mlprime;lădŭ&mlprime;, twelve.
Tâle&mlprime;danigi&mlprime;sk&ibreve; (Utâle&mlprime;danigi&mlprime;s&ibreve;, in a dialectic form)—variously rendered by the whites “Hemp-carrier,” “Nettle-carrier” or “Flax-toter,” from tâle&mlprime;ta or utâle&mlprime;ta, flax (Linum) or rich weed (Pilea pumila), and danigi&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, “he carries them (habitually).” A former prominent chief on Valley river, in Cherokee county, North Carolina. See number 95 and notes.
Talihina—given as the name of the Cherokee wife of Samuel Houston; the form cannot be identified. See page 223.
Tălikwă&mlprime; (commonly written Tellico, Telliquo or, in the Indian Territory, Tahlequah)—the name of several Cherokee settlements at different periods, viz: 1. Great Tellico, at Tellico Plains, on Tellico river, in Monroe county, Tennessee; 2. Little Tellico, on Tellico creek of Little Tennessee river, about ten miles below Franklin, in Macon county, North Carolina; 3. a town on Valley river, about five miles above Murphy, in Cherokee county, North Carolina; 4. Tahlequah, established as the capital of the Cherokee Nation, Indian Territory, in 1839. The meaning of the name is lost.
Tali&mlprime;wă—the site of a traditional battle between the Cherokee and Creeks about 1755, on Mountain (?) creek of Etowah river in upper Georgia. Probably not a Cherokee but a Creek name from the Creek ta&mlprime;lua or ita&mlprime;lua, town. See pages 38 and 384–385.
Talking-rock—see Nûñyû&mlprime;-gûñwani&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Tallulah—see Tălulŭ&mlprime;.
Tăl-tsu&mlprime;skă&mlprime;— “Two-heads,” from tă&mlprime;l&ibreve;, two, and tsu&mlprime;skă&mlprime;, plural of uskă&mlprime;, (his) head. A Cherokee chief about the year 1800, known to the whites as Doublehead.
talul&ibreve;—pregnant; whence alul&ibreve;&mlprime;, (she is) a mother, said of a woman.
Tălulŭ&mlprime; (commonly written Tallulah, and appearing in old documents, from the Lower dialect, as Taruraw, Toruro, Turoree, etc.)—a name occurring in two or more places in the old Cherokee country, viz: 1. An ancient settlement on the upper part of Tallulah river, in Rabun county, Georgia; 2. a town on Tallulah creek of Cheowa river, in Graham county, North Carolina. The word is of uncertain etymology. The dulu&mlprime;s&ibreve; frog is said to cry tălulŭ&mlprime;. See number 125. The noted falls upon Tallulah river are known to the Cherokee as Ugûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, q.v.
Taluntiski—see Ata&mlprime;lûñti&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Tama&okina;li—a name, commonly written Tomotley or Tomatola, occurring in at least two places in the old Cherokee country, viz: 1. On Valley river, a few miles above Murphy, about the present Tomatola, in Cherokee county, North Carolina; 2. on Little Tennessee river, about Tomotley ford, a few miles above Tellico river, in Monroe county, Tennessee. The name can not be translated, and may be of Creek origin, as that tribe had a town of the same name upon the lower Chattahoochee river.
Tănăs&ibreve;&mlprime;—a name which can not be analyzed, commonly spelt Tennessee, occurring in several places in the old Cherokee country, viz: 1. On Little Tennessee river, about halfway between Citico and Toco creeks, in Monroe county, Tennessee; 2. “Old Tennessee town,” on Hiwassee river, a short distance above the junction of Ocoee, in Polk county, Tennessee; 3. on Tennessee creek, a head-stream of Tuckasegee river, in Jackson county, North Carolina. Tanasqui, visited by Pardo in 1567 (see page 29), may have been another place of the same name. See number 124.
Tanasqui—see Tănăs&ibreve;.
Ta&okina;ski&mlprime;gi (abbreviated from Ta&okina;skigi&mlprime;y&ibreve; or Da&okina;skigi&mlprime;y&ibreve;, the locative y&ibreve; being commonly omitted)—a name variously written Tae-keo-ge (misprint), Tasquiqui, Teeskege, Tuscagee, Tuskegee, etc. derived from that of a foreign tribe incorporated with the Cherokee, and occurring as a local name both in the Cherokee and in the Creek country. 1. The principal settlement of this name was on Little Tennessee river, just above the junction of Tellico, in Monroe county, Tennessee; 2. another was on the north bank of Tennessee river, just below Chattanooga, Tennessee; 3. another may have been on Tuskegee creek of Little Tennessee river, near Robbinsville, Graham county, North Carolina. See page 29 and number 105.
Tasquiqui—see Ta&okina;ski&mlprime;gi.
Tassel, Old—see Utsi&mlprime;dsătă&mlprime;.
Tăts&ibreve;&mlprime;—“Dutch,” also written Tahchee, a western Cherokee chief about 1830. See page 141.
tatsu&mlprime;hwă—the redbird.
tawa&mlprime;l&ibreve;—punk.
Tawa&mlprime;l&ibreve;-ukwanûñ&mlprime;t&ibreve;—“Punk-plugged-in,” from tawa&mlprime;l&ibreve;, punk; the Cherokee name of a traditional Shawano chief. See number 100.
tăwi&mlprime;skă, tăwi&mlprime;skage—smooth, slick.
Tăwi&mlprime;skălă—“Flint”; a Cherokee supernatural, the personification of the rock flint; tăwi&mlprime;skălûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, tăwi&mlprime;skălă, flint, from tăwi&mlprime;skă, smooth, slick; cf. Iroquois Tăwiskaroñ. See number 25 and notes.
Tayûnks&ibreve;—a traditional western tribe; the name can not be analyzed. See number 105.
Tellico—see Tălikwă&mlprime;.
telûñ&mlprime;lăt&ibreve;—the summer grape (Vitis æstivalis).
Tensawattee—see Ku&mlprime;săweti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Terrapin—see Tûksi&mlprime;.
tewa—flying squirrel; sălâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;, gray squirrel; kiyu&okina;ga, ground squirrel.
Thomas, W. H.—see Wil-usdi&mlprime;.
T&ibreve;kwăli&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—a name occurring in several places in the old Cherokee country, viz: 1. Tuckalegee creek, a tributary of War-woman creek, east of Clayton, in Rabun county, Georgia; 2. the T&ibreve;kwăli&mlprime;ts&ibreve; of the story, an important town on Tuckasegee river at the present Bryson City, in Swain county, North Carolina; 3. Tuckalechee cove, on Little river, in Blount county, Tennessee, which probably preserves the aboriginal local name. The name appears in old documents as Tuckarechee (Lower dialect) and Tuckalegee, and must not be confounded with Ts&ibreve;ks&ibreve;&mlprime;ts&ibreve; or Tuckasegee. It can not be translated. See number 100 and notes.
Timossy—see Tomassee.
Tlâge&mlprime;s&ibreve;—“Field”; the Cherokee name for Lieutenant-Colonel W. W. Stringfield of Waynesville, North Carolina, one of the officers of the Cherokee contingent in the Thomas Legion. It is an abbreviated rendering of his proper name.
tlâge&mlprime;sitûñ&mlprime;—a song form for tlâge&mlprime;s&ibreve; a-stûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, “on the edge of the field,” from tlâge&mlprime;s&ibreve;, or tsâge&mlprime;s&ibreve;, field, and astûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, edge, border, etc; ăma&mlprime;yăstûñ&mlprime;, “the bank of a stream.” See number 24.
tla&mlprime;mehă—bat (dialectic forms, tsa&mlprime;mehă, tsa&mlprime;wehă). See page 187.
tlanu&mlprime;s&ibreve;&mlprime;—leech (dialectic form, tsanu&mlprime;s&ibreve;&mlprime;). See page 187.
Tlanusi&mlprime;y&ibreve; (abbreviated Tlanusi&mlprime;)—“Leech place,” a former important settlement at the junction of Hiwassee and Valley rivers, the present site of Murphy, in Cherokee county, North Carolina; also a point on Nottely river, a few miles distant, in the same county. See number 77 and notes. The name appears also as Clennuse, Klausuna, Quoneashee, etc.
tlă&mlprime;nuwă&mlprime; (dialectic forms, tsănuwă&mlprime;, sû&mlprime;năwă&mlprime;, “sinnawah”—Adair)—a mythic great hawk. See numbers 35, 64, 65, also page 187.
tlă&mlprime;nuwă&mlprime; usdi&mlprime;—“little tlă&mlprime;nuwă&mlprime;”; probably the goshawk (Astur atricapillus). See number 35.
Tlă&mlprime;nuwă&mlprime;-atsiyelûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;sûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the Tlă&mlprime;nuwă cut it up,” from tlă&mlprime;nuwă&mlprime;, q.v., and tsiyelûñ&mlprime;iskû&mlprime;, an archaic form for tsigûñilûñ&mlprime;iskû&mlprime;, “I am cutting it up.” A place on Little Tennessee river, nearly opposite the entrance of Citico creek, in Blount county, Tennessee. See number 64 and notes.
Tlă&mlprime;nuwa&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Tlă&mlprime;nuwă place,” a cave on the north side of Tennessee river a short distance below the entrance of Citico creek, in Blount county, Tennessee. See number 64 and notes.
tlay&mlapos;kû&mlprime;—jay (dialectic form, tsay&mlapos;kû&mlprime;). See page 187.
tlûñti&mlprime;st&ibreve;—the pheasant (Bonasa umbella), called locally grouse or partridge.
tlutlŭ&mlprime;—the martin bird (dialectic form, tsutsŭ&mlprime;). See page 187.
tsûñtû&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—panther (dialectic form, tsûñtû&mlprime;ts&ibreve;). See page 187.
Tocax—a place, apparently in the Cherokee country, visited by Pardo in 1567 (see page 29). It may possibly have a connection with Toxaway (see Dûksa&mlprime;&ibreve;) or Toccoa (see Tagwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;).
Toccoa—see Tagwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Toco—see Dăkwâ&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Tollunteeskee—see Ata&mlprime;lûñti&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Tomassee (also written Timossy and Tymahse)—the name of two or more former Cherokee settlements, viz: 1. On Tomassee creek of Keowee river, in Oconee county, South Carolina; 2. on Little Tennessee river near the entrance of Burningtown creek, in Macon county, South Carolina. The correct form and interpretation are unknown.
Tomatola, Tomotley—see Tama&okina;l&ibreve;.
Tooantuh—see Du&mlprime;stu&mlprime;.
Toogelah—see Dugilu&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Toqua—see Dăkwâ&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Toxaway—see Dûksa&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Track Rock gap—see Datsu&mlprime;nalâsgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Tsăga&mlprime;s&ibreve;—a Cherokee sprite. See number 78.
tsâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;—upstream, up the road; the converse of ge&mlprime;&ibreve;. See number 117.
Tsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime;—see Ûñtsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Tsa&mlprime;lădih&ibreve;&mlprime;—Chief N. J. Smith of the East Cherokee. The name might be rendered “Charley-killer,” from Tsal&ibreve;, “Charley,” and dih&ibreve;&mlprime;, “killer” (in composition), but is really a Cherokee equivalent for Jarrett (Tsalăd&ibreve;), his middle name, by which he was frequently addressed. Cf. Tagwădih&ibreve;.
tsâl-agăyûñ&mlprime;li—“old tobacco,” from tsâlû, tobacco, and agăyûñ&mlprime;li, or agâyûñ&mlprime;lige, old, ancient; the Nicotiana rustica or wild tobacco. See number 126.
Tsa&mlprime;lăg&ibreve;&mlprime; (Tsa&mlprime;răg&ibreve;&mlprime; in Lower dialect)—the correct form of Cherokee. See page 182, “Tribal Synonymy.”
Tsa&mlprime;l&ibreve;—Charley; a Cherokee shot for resisting the troops at the time of the Removal. See page 131.
tsâliyu&mlprime;st&ibreve;—“tobacco-like,” from tsâlû, tobacco, and iyu&mlprime;st&ibreve;, like; a generic name for the cardinal-flower, mullein and related species. See number 126.
tsâlû or tsâlûñ (in the Lower dialect, tsârû)—tobacco; by comparison with kindred forms in other Iroquoian dialects the meaning “fire to hold in the mouth” seems to be indicated. Lanman spells it tso-lungh. See number 126 and page 187.
tsa&mlprime;mehă—see tla&mlprime;mehă.
tsă&mlprime;nadiskâ&mlprime;—for tsăndiskâ&ibreve;, “they say.”
tsana&mlprime;sehâ&mlprime;&ibreve;—so they say, they say about him. See number 118.
tsâne&mlprime;n&ibreve;—the scorpion lizard; also called gi&mlprime;gă-danegi&mlprime;ski, q.v. See number 59.
Tsan&ibreve;—John.
Tsantăwû&mlprime;—a masculine name which can not be analyzed.
Tsan-uga&mlprime;s&ibreve;tă—“Sour John”; John Butler, a halfbreed Cherokee ball captain, formerly living on Nottely river. See number 122.
Tsan-usdi&mlprime;—“Little John”; the Cherokee name for General John Sevier, and also the boy name of the chief John Ross, afterward known as Gu&mlprime;wisguw&ibreve;&mlprime;, q.v. Sikwi&mlprime;ă, a Cherokee attempt at “Sevier,” is a masculine name upon the East Cherokee reservation.
tsanu&mlprime;s&ibreve;&mlprime;—see tlanu&mlprime;s&ibreve;&mlprime;.
tsă&mlprime;nuwă&mlprime;—see tlă&mlprime;nuwă&mlprime;.
Tsa&mlprime;răg&ibreve;&mlprime;—Cherokee; see page 182, “Tribal Synonymy.”
tsârû—see tsâlû.
Tsasta&mlprime;w&ibreve;—a noted hunter formerly living upon Nantahala river, in Macon county, North Carolina; the meaning of the name is doubtful. See number 122.
Tsatănu&mlprime;g&ibreve; (commonly spelled Chattanooga)—the Cherokee name for some point upon the creek entering Tennessee river at the city of Chattanooga, in Hamilton county, Tennessee. It has no meaning in the Cherokee language and appears to be of foreign origin. The ancient name for the site of the present city is A&okina;tlă&mlprime;nuwă, q.v. See number 124. Before the establishment of the town the place was known to the whites as Ross' landing, from a store kept there by Lewis Ross, brother of the chief John Ross.
Tsatu&mlprime;g&ibreve; (commonly written Chattooga or Chatuga)—a name occurring in two or more places in the old Cherokee country, but apparently of foreign origin (see page 382). Possible Cherokee derivations are from words signifying respectively “he drank by sips,” from gatu&mlprime;giă&mlprime;, “I sip,” or “he has crossed the stream and come out upon the other side,” from gatu&mlprime;g&ibreve;, “I have crossed” etc. An ancient settlement of this name was on Chattooga river, a head-stream of Savannah river, on the boundary between South Carolina and Georgia; another appears to have been on upper Tellico river, in Monroe county, Tennessee; another may have been on Chattooga river, a tributary of the Coosa, in northwestern Georgia.
Tsâ&mlprime;wă Gaksk&ibreve;—Joe Smoker, from Tsâwă, “Joe,” and gaksk&ibreve;, “smoker,” from ga&mlprime;giskû, “I am smoking.” The Cherokee name for Chief Joel B. Mayes, of the Cherokee Nation west.
Tsăwa&mlprime;s&ibreve;—a Cherokee sprite. See number 78.
tsa&mlprime;wehă—see tla&mlprime;mehă.
tsay&mlapos;kû&mlprime;—see tlay'kû&mlprime;.
Tsek&mlprime;s&ibreve;n&ibreve;&mlprime;—the Cherokee form for the name of General Andrew Jackson.
Ts&ebreve;sa&mlprime;n&ibreve;—Jessan, probably a derivative from Jesse; a masculine name upon the East Cherokee reservation.
Ts&ebreve;&mlprime;s&ibreve;-Ska&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—“Scotch Jesse”; Jesse Reid, present chief of the East Cherokee, so called because of mixed Scotch ancestry.
tsetsăni&mlprime;l&ibreve;—“thy two elder brothers” (male speaking); my elder brother (male speaking), ûñgini&mlprime;l&ibreve;. See note to number 63.
Tsgâgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Insect place,” from tsgâyă, insect, and y&ibreve;, locative. A cave in the ridge eastward from Franklin, in Macon county, North Carolina. See number 13.
tsgâyă—insect, worm, etc. See page 308.
Ts&ibreve;kăma&mlprime;g&ibreve;—a name, commonly spelled Chickamauga, occurring in at least two places in the old Cherokee country, which has lost any meaning in Cherokee and appears to be of foreign origin. It is applied to a small creek at the head of Chattahoochee river, in White county, Georgia, and also to the district about the southern (not the northern) Chickamauga creek, coming into Tennessee river, a few miles above Chattanooga, in Hamilton county, Tennessee. In 1777 the more hostile portion of the Cherokee withdrew from the rest of the tribe and established here a large settlement, from which they removed about five years later to settle lower down the Tennessee in what were known as the Chickamauga towns or Five Lower towns. See page 54 and number 124.
ts&ibreve;k&ibreve;&mlprime;—a word which renders emphatic that which it follows: as â&mlprime;stû, “very good,” âstû&mlprime; ts&ibreve;k&ibreve;, “best of all.” See number 75.
ts&ibreve;k&ibreve;k&ibreve;&mlprime;—the katydid; the name is an onomatope.
ts&ibreve;&mlprime;k&ibreve;lil&ibreve;&mlprime;—the Carolina chickadee (Parus carolinensis); the name is an onomatope. See number 35.
Ts&ibreve;ksi&mlprime;ts&ibreve; (Tûksi&mlprime;ts&ibreve; in dialectic form; commonly written Tuckasegee)—1. a former Cherokee settlement about the junction of the two forks of Tuckasegee, above Webster, in Jackson county, North Carolina (not to be confounded with T&ibreve;kwăli&mlprime;ts&ibreve;, q.v.). 2. A former settlement on a branch of Brasstown creek of Hiwassee river, in Towns county, Georgia. The word has lost its meaning.
Ts&ibreve;&mlprime;naw&ibreve;—a Cherokee wheelwright, perhaps the first in the Nation to make a spinning wheel and loom. The name can not be analyzed. See page 214.
ts&ibreve;ne&mlprime;û—I am picking it (something long) up; in the Lower and Middle dialects, ts&ibreve;nigi&mlprime;û.
ts&ibreve;nigi&mlprime;û—see ts&ibreve;ne&mlprime;û.
tsiska&mlprime;g&ibreve;l&ibreve;—the large red crawfish; the ordinary crawfish is called tsistû&mlprime;na. See number 59.
tsi&mlprime;skwa—bird.
tsiskwa&mlprime;gwă—robin, from tsi&mlprime;skwa, bird.
Tsiskwâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Bird place,” from tsi&mlprime;skwa, bird, and h&ibreve;, locative. Birdtown settlement on the East Cherokee reservation, in Swain county, North Carolina.
tsiskwâ&mlprime;yă—sparrow, literally “principal bird” (i.e., most widely distributed), from tsi&mlprime;skwa, bird, and yâ, a suffix denoting principal or real.
Tsilalu&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Sweet-gum place,” from tsila&mlprime;lŭ&mlprime;, sweet-gum (Liquidambar), and h&ibreve;, locative. A former settlement on a small branch of Brasstown creek of Hiwassee river, just within the line of Towns county, Georgia. The name is incorrectly rendered Gumlog (creek).
Tsiskwunsdi&mlprime;-adsisti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they killed Little-bird,” from Tsiskw-unsdi&mlprime;, “Little-birds” (plural form). A place near the head of West Buffalo creek, southeast of Robbinsville, in Graham county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Tsistetsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Mouse place,” from tsistets&ibreve;, mouse, and y&ibreve;, locative; a former settlement on South Mouse creek, of Hiwassee river, in Bradley county, Tennessee. The present town of Cleveland, upon the same creek, is known to the Cherokee under the same name.
tsistu—rabbit.
tsistû&mlprime;na—crawfish; the large horned beetle is also so called. The large red crawfish is called tsiska&mlprime;g&ibreve;l&ibreve;.
tsist-uni&mlprime;gist&ibreve;—“rabbit foods” (plural), from tsi&mlprime;stu, rabbit, and uni&mlprime;gist&ibreve;, plural of agi&mlprime;st&ibreve;, food, from tsiy&ibreve;&mlprime;giû “I am eating” (soft food). The wild rose.
Tsistu&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Rabbit place,” from tsistu, rabbit, and y&ibreve;, locative. 1. Gregory bald, high peak of the Great Smoky range, eastward from Little Tennessee river, on the boundary between Swain county, North Carolina and Blount county, Tennessee. See number 75 and notes. 2. A former settlement on the north bank of Hiwassee river at the, entrance of Chestua creek, in Polk county, Tennessee. The name of Choastea creek of Tugaloo river, in Oconee county, South Carolina, is probably also a corruption from the same word.
Tsiyâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Otter place,” from tsiyû, otter, and y&ibreve;, locative; variously spelled Cheowa, Cheeowhee, Chewohe, Chewe, etc. 1. A former settlement on a branch of Keowee river, near the present Cheohee, Oconee county, South Carolina. 2. A former and still existing Cherokee settlement on Cheowa river, about Robbinsville, in Graham county, North Carolina. 3. A former settlement in Cades cove, on Cove creek, in Blount county, Tennessee.
Tsi&mlprime;yu-gûnsi&mlprime;n&ibreve;—“He is dragging a canoe,” from tsi&mlprime;yŭ, canoe (cf. tsi&mlprime;yû, otter) and gûnsi&mlprime;n&ibreve;, “he is dragging it.” “Dragging-canoe,” a prominent leader of the hostile Cherokee in the Revolution. The name appears in documents as Cheucunsene and Kunnesee. See page 54.
Tsk&ibreve;l-e&mlprime;gwă—“Big-witch,” from atsk&ibreve;l&ibreve;&mlprime;, or tsk&ibreve;l&ibreve;&mlprime;, witch, owl, and e&mlprime;gwa, big; an old man of the East Cherokee, who died in 1896. See page 179. Although translated Big-witch by the whites, the name is understood by the Indians to mean Big-owl (see number 35), having been originally applied to a white man living on the same clearing, noted for his large staring eyes.
tsk&ibreve;l&ibreve;&mlprime; (contracted from atsk&ibreve;l&ibreve;&mlprime;)—1. witch; 2. the dusky horned owl (Bubo virginianus saturatus). See number 35.
TSOLUNGH—see tsălû.
tskwâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—the great white heron or American egret (Herodias egretta).
Tsudâ&mlprime;tălesûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where pieces fall off,” i.e. where the banks are caving in; from adâtăle&mlprime;û, “it is falling off,” ts, distance prefix, “there,” and y&ibreve;, locative. The Cherokee name for the present site of Memphis, Tennessee, overlooking the Mississippi, and formerly known as the Chickasaw bluff.
Tsuda&mlprime;ye&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Isolated place”; an isolated peak near the head of Cheowa river, northeast of Robbinsville, in Graham county, North Carolina. See number 79 and notes. The root of the word signifies detached, or isolated, whence Uda&mlprime;ye&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, the Cherokee outlet, in the Indian Territory.
Tsu&mlprime;dinûñti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Throwing-down place”; a former settlement on lower Nantahala river, in Macon county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Tsugidû&okina;l&ibreve; ûlsgi&mlprime;st&ibreve; (from tsugidû&okina;l&ibreve;, plural of ugidû&okina;l&ibreve;, one of the long wing or tail feathers of a bird, and ûlsgi&mlprime;st&ibreve; or ûlsgi&mlprime;ta, a dance)—the feather or eagle dance. See number 35.
tsûñgili&mlprime;s&ibreve;—plural of ûñgili&mlprime;s&ibreve;, q.v.
tsûñgini&mlprime;s&ibreve;—plural of ûñgini&mlprime;s&ibreve;, q.v.
Tsukilûñnûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where he alighted”; two bald spots on a mountain at the head of Little Snowbird creek, near Robbinsville, in Graham county, North Carolina. For tradition, see number 122.
tsûñkina&mlprime;tl&ibreve;—“my younger brothers” (male speaking).
tsûñkită&mlprime;—“my younger brothers” (female speaking).
tsu&okina;lă—fox; cf. tsû&okina;lû, kingfisher and tlutlŭ&mlprime; or tsutsŭ&mlprime;, martin. The black fox is inâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;. The Creek word for fox is chula.
tsula&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—alligator: the name is of uncertain etymology.
Tsŭ&okina;la&mlprime;w&ibreve;—see Tsû&okina;lûñwe&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Tsulâ&mlprime;sinûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Footprint place.” A place on Tuckasegee river, about a mile above Deep creek, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Tsul&okina;kălû&mlprime;—“Slanting-eyes,” literally “He has them slanting” (or leaning up against something); the prefix ts makes it a plural form, and the name is understood
to refer to the eyes, although the word eye (aktă&mlprime;, plural diktă&mlprime;) is not a part of it. Cf. Ătă&mlprime;-gûl&okina;kălû&mlprime;. A mythic giant and ruler of the game. The name has been corrupted to Jutaculla and Tuli-cula. Jutaculla rock and Jutaculla old fields about the head of Tuckasegee river, in Jackson, North Carolina, take their name from him. See number 81 and notes.
Tsule&mlprime;hisanûñ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Resurrected One,” from di&mlprime;gwăle&mlprime;hisanûñ&mlprime;h&ibreve;, “I was resurrected,” literally, “I was down and have risen.” Tsa&mlprime;lăg&ibreve;&mlprime; Tsule&mlprime;hisanŭñh&ibreve;, the Cherokee title of the newspaper known to the whites as the Cherokee Phœnix. The Cherokee title was devised by Worcester and Boudinot as suggesting the idea of the phœnix of classic fable. The Indian name of the recent “Cherokee Advocate” is Tsa&mlprime;lăg&ibreve; Asdeli&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Tsul&okina;kălû&mlprime; tsunegûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—see Tsunegûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
tsulie&mlprime;na—the nuthatch (Sitta carolinensis); the word signifies literally “deaf” (a plural form referring to the ear, gûl&ebreve;&mlprime;), although no reason is given for such a name.
tsû&okina;lû—kingfisher. Cf. tsu&okina;lă.
Tsû&okina;lûñwe&mlprime;&ibreve; (abbreviated Tsû&okina;lûñ&mlprime;we or Tsûla&mlprime;w&ibreve;, possibly connected with tsû&okina;lû, kingfisher)—Chilhowee creek, a north tributary of Little Tennessee river, in Blount county, Tennessee.
Tsunda&okina;nilti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they demanded the debt from him”; a place on Little Santeetla river, west of Robbinsville, in Graham county, North Carolina. The creek also is commonly known by the same name. See number 122.
Tsundige&mlprime;w&ibreve;—“Closed anuses,” literally “They have them closed,” understood to refer to the anus; from dige&mlprime;w&ibreve;, plural of ge&mlprime;w&ibreve;, closed, stopped up, blind; cf. Tsul&okina;kălû&mlprime;; also Gûlisge&mlprime;w&ibreve;, “Blind, or closed, ears,” an old personal name. See number 74.
tsun&mlprime;digwûn&mlprime;tsk&ibreve; (contracted from tsun&mlprime;digwûntsu&okina;g&ibreve;, “they have them forked,” referring to the peculiar forked tail; cf. Tsul&okina;kălû&mlprime;)—a migratory bird which once appeared for a short time upon the East Cherokee reservation, apparently, from the description, the scissortail or swallow-tailed flycatcher (Milvulus forficatus). See number 35.
Tsunegûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve; (sometimes called Tsul&okina;kălû&mlprime; Tsunegûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;&mlprime;)—Tennessee bald, at the extreme head of Tuckasegee river, on the east line of Jackson county, North Carolina. The name seems to mean, “There where it is white,” from ts, a prefix indicating distance, une&mlprime;gă, white, and y&ibreve;, locative. See number 81 and notes.
Tsunil&mlprime;&okina;kălû—the plural form for Tsul&okina;kălû, q.v.; a traditional giant tribe in the west. See number 106.
tsunû&mlprime;&okina;liyû&mlprime;sûn&ebreve;stlâ&mlprime;tă—“they have split noses,” from agwa&okina;liyû&mlprime;, “I have it,” and un&ebreve;stlâû&mlprime;, “it is cracked” (as a crack made by the sun's heat in a log or in the earth); the initial s makes it refer to the nose, kăyăsă&mlprime;. See number 76 and notes.
tsun&ibreve;s&mlprime;tsăh&ibreve;&mlprime;—“(those) having topknots or crests,” from ustdăhû&mlprime;, “having a topknot,” ustsăh&ibreve;&mlprime;, “he has a topknot” (habitual). See number 76 and notes.
Tsuniya&mlprime;tigă—“Naked People”; literally “They are naked there,” from uya&mlprime;tigă, naked (singular), with the prefix ts, indicating distance. A traditional western tribe. See number 105.
tsunsdi&mlprime;—contracted from tsunsdi&mlprime;ga, the plural of usdi&mlprime;ga or usdi&mlprime;, small.
Tsunu&mlprime;lăhûñ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;— “He tries, but fails” (habitually), from detsinu&mlprime;lăhûñ&mlprime;gû&mlprime; (q.v.), “I tried, but failed.” A former noted chief among the East Cherokee, commonly known to the whites as Junaluska. In early life he was called Gûl&okina;kăla&mlprime;sk&ibreve;, a name which denotes something habitually falling from a leaning position (cf. Ătă-gûl&okina;kălû&mlprime; and Tsul&okina;kălû&mlprime;.) See page 164.
tsûñ-ka&mlprime;wi-ye&mlprime;, tsûñ-s&ibreve;kwa-ya&mlprime;, tsûñ-tsu&mlprime;la-ya&mlprime;, tsûñ-wa&mlprime;&okina;ya-ya&mlprime;—“I am (tsûñ or tsi,
verbal prefix) a real (yă, ye, noun suffix) deer” (kaw&ibreve;&mlprime;, archaic for a&okina;w&ibreve;&mlprime;); opossum, s&ibreve;&mlprime;kwa; fox, tsu&okina;lă; wolf, wa&okina;ya. Archaic song forms. See number 15.
Tsûsginâ&mlprime;&ibreve;—“the Ghost country,” from asgi&mlprime;na, “ghost,” &ibreve;, locative, and ts, a prefix denoting distance. The land of the dead; it is situated in Usûñhi&mlprime;y&ibreve;, the Twilight land, in the west. See number 5.
tsuakwa&okina;l&ibreve;—plural of uskwa&okina;l&ibreve;, short.
Tsuskwănûñ&mlprime;năwa&mlprime;tă—“Worn-out blanket,” from tsuskwănûñ&mlprime;n&ibreve;, blanket (the word refers to something having stripes), and uwa&mlprime;tă, “worn out.” James D. Wafford, a prominent Cherokee mixed-blood and informant in the Western nation, who died about 1896. See page 236.
Tsûta&mlprime;ga Uweyûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Chicken creek,” from tsûta&mlprime;ga, chicken, and uweyûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, stream. An extreme eastern head-stream of Nantahala river, in Macon county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Tsuta&mlprime;tsinasûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Eddy place.” A place on Cheowa river at the mouth of Cockram creek, in Graham county, North Carolina. For tradition see number 122.
tsutsŭ&mlprime;—see tlutlŭ&mlprime;.
tsûñtû&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—see tlûñtû&mlprime;ts&ibreve;.
tsuwă&mlprime;—the mud-puppy or water-dog (Menopoma or Protonopsis). See number 59.
Tsuwa&okina;tel&mlprime;da—a contraction of Tsuwa&okina;teldûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;; the name has lost its meaning. Pilot knob, north from Brevard, in Transylvania county, North Carolina. See number 82 and notes.
Tsuwa&mlprime;-uniyetsûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the water-dogs laughed,” from tsuwă&mlprime; (q.v.), “water-dog,” uniye&mlprime;tsû, “they laughed” (agiyet&mlprime;skû, “I am laughing”), and y&ibreve;, locative; Tusquittee bald, near Hayesville, in Clay county, North Carolina. For story see number 122.
Tsuwe&mlprime;năh&ibreve;—A traditional hunter, in communication with the invisible people. See number 83. The name seems to mean “He has them in abundance,” an irregular or archaic form for Uwe&mlprime;nă&ibreve;, “he has abundance,” “he is rich,” from agwe&mlprime;nă&ibreve;&mlprime;, “I am rich.” As a masculine name it is used as the equivalent of Richard. See number 83.
Tuckalechee—see T&ibreve;kwăli&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
Tuckasegee—see Ts&ibreve;ksi&mlprime;ta&ibreve;.
Tugaloo—see Dugilu&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
tugalŭ!—the cry of the dagûl&okina;kû goose.
tugălû&mlprime;nă—a variety of small fish, about four inches long, frequenting the larger streams (from gălû&mlprime;nă, a gourd, on account of its long nose). See number 39 and notes.
tûks&ibreve;&mlprime;—the terrapin or land tortoise; also the name of a Cherokee chief about the close of the Revolution. Săligu&mlprime;g&ibreve;, common turtle; soft-shell turtle, u&okina;lănă&mlprime;wă.
Tûksi&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—see Ts&ibreve;ksi&mlprime;ts&ibreve;.
Tuli-cula—see Tsul&okina;kălû&mlprime;.
tûlsku&mlprime;wa—“he snaps with his head,” from uskă&mlprime;, head; the snapping beetle.
Tunâ&mlprime;&ibreve;—a traditional warrior and medicine-man of old Itsâ&mlprime;t&ibreve;; the name can not be analyzed. See number 99.
Turkeytown—see Gûn-di&mlprime;gaduhûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Turniptown—see U&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Tuskegee—see Ta&okina;ski&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Tusquittee bald—see Tsuwă&mlprime;-uniyetsûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Tusquittee creek—see Daskw&ibreve;tûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
tu&mlprime;sti—for tusti&mlprime;gă, a small bowl; larger jars are called diwa&mlprime;&okina;l&ibreve; and ûñti&mlprime;yă.
tûñ&mlprime;tăwû&mlprime;—a small yellow night-moth. The name comes from ahûñ&mlprime;tû, a word implying that something flits into and out of the blaze. See number 59.
tu&mlprime;t&ibreve;—snowbird.
Tuti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Snowbird place,” from tu&mlprime;t&ibreve;, snowbird, and y&ibreve;, locative. Little Snow-bird creek of Cheowa river, in Graham county, North Carolina.
tû&mlprime;tsahyes&ibreve;&mlprime;—“he will marry you.”
tu&mlprime;yă—bean.
tu&mlprime;yă-d&ibreve;skalaw&okina;sti&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—see ta&mlprime;gû.
tû&mlprime;yahus&ibreve;&mlprime;—“she will die.”
Tymahse—see Tomassee.
Uchee—see Ani&mlprime;-Yu&mlprime;ts&ibreve;.
udâ&mlprime;hale&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“on the sunny side.”
udâ&mlprime;&ibreve;—the baneberry or cohosh vine (Actæa?). The name signifies that the plant has something long hanging from it.
uda&okina;l&ibreve;—“(it is) married”; the mistletoe, so called on account of its parasitic habit.
U&mlprime;dăwagûñ&mlprime;ta—“Bald.” A bald mountain of the Great Smoky range, in Yancey county, North Carolina, not far from Mount Mitchell. See number 51.
Udsi&mlprime;skală—a masculine name.
uga&mlprime;s&ibreve;tă—sour.
ûñgidă&mlprime;—“thy two elder brothers” (male speaking). See notes to number 63.
ûñgili&mlprime;s&ibreve; (plural, tsûñgili&mlprime;s&ibreve;)—“my daughter's child.” See note to number 66, and cf. ûñgini&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
ûñgini&mlprime;l&ibreve;—“my elder brother” (female speaking). See notes to number 63.
ûñgini&mlprime;s&ibreve; (plural tsûñgini&mlprime;s&ibreve;)—“my son's child.” See note to number 66, and cf. ûñgili&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
u&mlprime;giskă&mlprime;—“he is swallowing it”; from ts&ibreve;kiû&mlprime;, “I am eating.” See number 8 and notes.
u&mlprime;guku&mlprime;—the hooting or barred owl (Syrnium nebulosum); the name is an onomatope. See also tsk&ibreve;l&ibreve;&mlprime; and wa&mlprime;&okina;huhu&mlprime;.
ugûñste&mlprime;l&ibreve; (ugûñste&mlprime;lû in dialectic form)—the hornyhead fish (Campostoma, stone roller). The name is said, on doubtful authority, to refer to its having horns. See number 59.
Ugŭñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—Tallulah falls, on the river of that name, northeast from Clarkesville, in Habersham county, Georgia; the meaning of the name is lost. See number 84.
Uilata—See U&okina;tlûñ&mlprime;tă.
uk-ku&mlprime;sûñtsût&ebreve;t&ibreve;&mlprime;—“it will twist up one's arm.” See number 115.
Uk-ku&mlprime;sûñtsût&ibreve;—“Bent-bow-shape”; a comic masculine name. Cf. gûltsû&mlprime;t&ibreve;, bow. See number 115.
uk-kwûnăgi&mlprime;st&ibreve;—“it will draw down one's eye.” See number 115.
Uk-kwûnăgi&mlprime;ta—“Eye-drawn-down”; a comic masculine name. See number 115.
uksu&mlprime;h&ibreve;—the mountain blacksnake or black racer (Coluber obsoletus); the name seems to refer to some peculiarity of the eye, aktă&mlprime;; uksuhă&mlprime;, “he has something lodged in his eye.” See number 53 and notes.
Ukte&mlprime;na—“Keen-eyed (?)” from aktă&mlprime;, eye, akta&mlprime;t&ibreve;, to examine closely. A mythic great horned serpent, with a talismanic diadem. See number 50 and notes.
Ukte&mlprime;na-tsuganûñ&mlprime;tatsûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the Uktena got fastened.” A spot on Tuckasegee river, about two miles above Bryson City, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Uktena-utansi&mlprime;nastûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the Uktena crawled.” A rock on the north bank of Tuckasegee river, about four miles above Bryson City, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Ukwû&mlprime;nû (or Ukwû&mlprime;n&ibreve;)—a former Cherokee settlement, commonly known to the whites as Oconee, on Seneca creek, near the present Walhalla, in Oconee county, South Carolina.
Ula&okina;gû&mlprime;—the mythic original of the yellow-jacket tribe. See number 13. The word signifies “leader,” “boss,” or “principal one,” and is applied to the first yellow-jacket (d&okina;ska&mlprime;&ibreve;) seen in the spring, to a queen bee and to the leader of a working squad.
u&okina;lănă&mlprime;wă—the soft-shell turtle; the etymology of the word is uncertain. See also săligu&mlprime;g&ibreve; and tûks&ibreve;&mlprime;.
ulasu&mlprime;la—moccasin, shoe.
ûl&ebreve;&mlprime;—and; ûl&ebreve;-&okina;nû&mlprime;, and also.
Ûñli&mlprime;ta—“(He is) long-winded,” an archaic form for the regular word, gûñli&mlprime;ta; an old masculine name. A chief about the year 1790, known to the whites as “The Breath.”
ûlskwûlte&mlprime;g&ibreve;—a “pound-mill,” a self-acting water-mill used in the Cherokee mountains. The name signifies that “it butts with its head” (uskă&mlprime;, head), in allusion to the way in which the pestle works in the mortar. The generic word for mill is dista&mlprime;st&ibreve;.
ulst&ibreve;tlû&mlprime;—literally, “it is on his head.” The diamond crest on the head of the mythic Uktena serpent. When detached it becomes the Ulûñsû&mlprime;t&ibreve;.
Ultiwâ&mlprime;&ibreve;—a former Cherokee settlement about the present Ooltewah, on the creek of the same name, in James county, Tennessee. The name has the locative form (&ibreve; suffix), but cannot be translated.
ulûñni&mlprime;ta—domesticated, tame; may be used for persons as well as animals, but not for plants; for cultivated or domesticated plants the adjective is gûnutlûñ&mlprime;&ibreve; (or gûnusûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;).
Ulûñsû&mlprime;t&ibreve;—“Transparent”; the great talismanic crystal of the Cherokee. Spelled Oolunsade by Hagar. See number 50 and notes.
ulûñ&mlprime;ta—“it has climbed,” from tsilah&ibreve;&mlprime;, “I am climbing”; the poison oak (Rhus radicans). See number 126.
U&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Tuber place,” from U&okina;l&ibreve;&mlprime;, a variety of edible tuber, and y&ibreve;, locative. A former settlement upon Turniptown (for U&okina;lûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;) creek, above Ellijay, in Gilmer county, Georgia.
Unacala—see Une&mlprime;gădih&ibreve;&mlprime;.
U&mlprime;nadanti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Place where they conjured,” the name of a gap about three miles east of Webster, in Jackson county, North Carolina, and now transferred to the town itself. See number 122.
unăde&mlprime;na—woolly, downy (in speaking of animals); uwă&mlprime;nû, wool, down, fine fur (detached from the animal).
u&mlprime;năhŭ&mlprime;—see unăhw&ibreve;&mlprime;.
unăhw&ibreve;&mlprime;—heart; in Middle and Lower dialects, unăhŭ&mlprime;. See page 187.
Unaka—see une&mlprime;gă and Unicoi.
unatlûñwe&mlprime;hitû—“it has spirals”; a plant (unidentified) used in conjurations. See number 126.
une&mlprime;gă—white.
une&mlprime;guh&ibreve;—“he is (was) mischievous or bad”; tsûne&mlprime;guhi&mlprime;yu, “you are very mischievous” (said to a child). See number 118.
une&mlprime;gutsătû&mlprime;—“(he is) mischievous”; a&mlprime;gine&mlprime;gutsătû&mlprime;, “I am mischievous.”
Une&okina;lănûñ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“The Apportioner”; “I am apportioning,” gane&okina;laskû&mlprime;; “I apportion” (habitually), gane&okina;lask&ibreve;. In the sacred formulas a title of the Sun god; in the Bible the name of God.
une&mlprime;stălûñ—ice.
Unicoi—the map name of the old Unicoi turnpike (see page 87), of a gap on the watershed between Chattahoochee and Hiwassee rivers, in Georgia, and of a county in eastern Tennessee. Probably a corruption of une&mlprime;gă, white, whence comes also Unaka, the present map name of a part of the Great Smoky range.
uni&mlprime;gist&ibreve;—foods; singular, agi&mlprime;st&ibreve;.
Uniga&mlprime;yata&okina;ti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they made a fish trap,” from uga&mlprime;yatûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, fish trap, and y&ibreve;, locative; a place on Tuckasegee river, at the mouth of Deep creek, near Bryson City, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 100 and notes.
Uni&mlprime;hăluna—see Ăhălu&mlprime;na.
Unika&mlprime;w&ibreve;—the “Townhouse dance,” so called because danced inside the townhouse; the name does not refer to a townhouse (gati&mlprime;y&ibreve;) and can not be analyzed, but may have some connection with the archaic word for deer. Cf. Ani&mlprime;-Kaw&ibreve;&mlprime;.
Une&mlprime;gă-dih&ibreve;&mlprime;—“White-man-killer”; from une&mlprime;ga, “white,” for yûñ&mlprime;wune&mlprime;ga, “white person,” and dih&ibreve;&mlprime;, a noun suffix denoting “killer” (“he kills them” habitually). A Cherokee chief, whose name appears in documents about 1790 as White-man-killer, or, by misprint Unacala. It is an old masculine name, existing until recently upon the reservation. Cf. Ta&mlprime;gwădih&ibreve;&mlprime;.
u&mlprime;niskwetu&okina;g&ibreve;—“they wear a hat”; ûlskwe&mlprime;tăwă&mlprime;, hat, from uskă&mlprime;, head. The may-apple (Podophyllum). See number 126.
unistilûñ&mlprime;ist&ibreve;—“they stick on along their whole length”; the generic name for “stickers” and burs, including the Spanish needle, cockle bur, jimson weed, etc. See number 126.
uni&mlprime;ts&ibreve;—her mother; agits&ibreve;&mlprime;, my mother.
Uniyâ&mlprime;hitûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they shot it,” from tsiyâ&mlprime;ihû, “I shoot,” and y&ibreve;, locative. A place on Tuckasegee river a short distance above Bryson City, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 100.
Untoola—see Dihyûñ&mlprime;dulă&mlprime;.
Unta&mlprime;kiyasti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they race,” from takiya&mlprime;tă, a race, and y&ibreve;, locative; locally corrupted to Tahkeyostee. The district on the French Broad river, around Asheville, in Buncombe county, North Carolina. The town itself is known to the Cherokee as Kâsdu&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Ashes place,” (from kâsdu, ashes, and y&ibreve;, locative), which is intended as a translation of its proper name. See number 122.
Untlasgâsti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where they scratched”; a place at the head of Hyatt creek of Valley river, in Cherokee county, North Carolina. For tradition see number 122.
Untoola—see Dihyûñ&mlprime;dulă&mlprime;.
unûñ&mlprime;t&ibreve;—milk.
usdi&mlprime;gâ (abbreviated usdi&mlprime;), small; plural tsunsdi&mlprime;gă, tsunsdi&mlprime;.
usga&mlprime;s&ebreve;&okina;ti&mlprime;yu—very dangerous, very terrible; intensive of usga&mlprime;s&ebreve;&okina;t&ibreve;.
Uskwăle&mlprime;na—“Big-head,” from uskă&mlprime;, head; a masculine name, perhaps the original of the “Bull-head,” given by Haywood as the name of a former noted Cherokee warrior.
Uskwâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;-gû&mlprime;tă—“His stomach hangs down,” from uskwâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;, his stomach, and gû&mlprime;tă, “it hangs down.” A prominent chief of the Revolutionary period, known to the whites as Hanging-maw.
U&okina;stăna&mlprime;l&ibreve; (from u&okina;stănalâ&mlprime;h&ibreve; or uni&mlprime;stăna&mlprime;lă (a plural form), denoting a natural barrier of rocks (plural) across a stream)—a name occurring in several places in the old Cherokee country, and variously spelled Eastinaulee, Eastanora, Estanaula, Eustenaree, Istanare, Oostanaula, Oostinawley, Ustenary, etc. One settlement of this name was on Keowee river, below the present Fort George, in Oconee county, South Carolina; another seems to have been somewhere on the waters of Tuckasegee river, in western North Carolina; a third, prominent during and after the Revolutionary period, was just above the junction of Coosawatee and Conasauga rivers to form the Oostanaula, in Gordon county, Georgia, and adjoining New Echota (see Gănsâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;). Other settlements of the same name may have been on Eastanollee creek of Tugaloo river, in Franklin county, Georgia, and on Eastaunaula creek, flowing into Hiwassee river, in McMinn county, Tennessee. Cf. Tsu&okina;stănalûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, under Dăgunâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
u&mlprime;stût&ibreve;—see utsu&okina;g&ibreve;.
Ustû&mlprime;tl&ibreve;—a traditional dangerous serpent. The name signifies having something on the calf of the leg or on the heel, from ustûtûñ&mlprime;&ibreve;, (his) calf of the leg (attached). It is applied also to the southern hoop-snake (Abastor erythrogrammus). See number 54.
Usûñhi&mlprime;y&ibreve;—the “Darkening land,” where it is always getting dark, as at twilight. The name used for the west in the myths and sacred formulas; the common word is wude&mlprime;ligûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “there where it (the sun) goes down.” In number 63 the word used is wusûhihûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “there where they stay over night.” See also Tsûsginâ&mlprime;&ibreve;.
u&mlprime;tănû—great, fully developed. Cf. e&mlprime;gwa.
utawâ&mlprime;hilû—“hand-breadth,” from uwâ&mlprime;yi, hand. A figurative term used in the myths and sacred formulas.
U&mlprime;tăwagûn&mlprime;ta—“Bald place.” A high bald peak of the Great Smoky range on the Tennessee-North Carolina line, northeastward from Big Pigeon river. See number 51.
Ûñ&mlprime;tiguh&ibreve;&mlprime;—“Pot in the water,” from ûñti&mlprime;yă, or ûñti&mlprime;, pot, and guh&ibreve;&mlprime;, “it is in the water” (or other liquid—habitually). The Suck, a dangerous rapid in Tennessee river, at the entrance of Suck creek, about eight miles below Chattanooga, Tennessee. See number 63 and notes.
U&okina;tlûñ&mlprime;tă—“He (or she) has it sharp,” i.e., has some sharp part or organ; it might be used of a tooth, finger-nail, or some other attached portion of the body, but in the story is understood to refer to the awl-like finger. Ten Kate spells it Uilata. A mythic half-human monster. See number 66 and notes.
U&okina;tlûñtûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“U&okina;tlûñ&mlprime;tă place;” see U&okina;tlûñ&mlprime;tă. A place on little Tennessee river, nearly off Citico creek, in Blount county, Tennessee. See number 66 and notes and number 124.
U&mlprime;tsălă—“Lichen”; another form of utsăle&mlprime;ta. A Cherokee chief of the Removal period. See page 157.
utsăle&mlprime;ta—lichen, literally “pot scrapings,” from a fancied resemblance.
Ûñtsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime; (also Etsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime; or Tsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime;, the first syllable being almost silent)—“Brass.” A mythic gambler. See number 63 and notes. The present rendering, “brass,” is probably a modern application of the old myth name, and is based upon the resemblance of the sound to that produced by striking a sheet of metal.
utsa&mlprime;năt&ibreve;&mlprime;—rattlesnake; the name is of doubtful etymology, but is said to refer to the rattle.
Utsa&mlprime;năti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Rattlesnake place.” Rattlesnake springs, about two miles south from Charleston, Bradley county, Tennessee. See page 132.
utset&mlprime;st&ibreve;—“he grins” (habitually). See s&ibreve;&mlprime;kwă utset&mlprime;st&ibreve;.
uts&ibreve;&mlprime;—her (his) mother; ets&ibreve;&mlprime;, agits&ibreve;&mlprime;, my mother.
Utsi&mlprime;dsătă&mlprime;—“Corn-tassel,” “Thistle-head,” etc. It is used as a masculine name and was probably the Cherokee name of the chief known during the Revolutionary period as “Old Tassel.”
utsu&mlprime;&okina;g&ibreve;—the tufted titmouse (Parus bicolor); also called u&mlprime;stût&ibreve;, “topknot, or tip.” on account of its crest. See numbers 35 and 66.
û&mlprime;tsût&ibreve;&mlprime;—fish. Cf. u&mlprime;tsût&ibreve;, many.
ûñwădâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;—store-house, provision house. See number 3 and notes.
Uñ&mlprime;wădâ-tsu&okina;gilasûñ&mlprime;—“Where the storehouse (ûñwâdâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;) was taken off.” Either Black rock or Jones knob, northeast of Webster, on the east line of Jackson county, in North Carolina. See number 122.
Uwagâ&mlprime;h&ibreve; (commonly written Ocoee)—“Apricot place,” from uwa&mlprime;gă, the “apricot vine,” or “maypop,” (Passiflora incarnata), and h&ibreve;, locative. A former important settlement on Ocoee river, near its junction with Hiwassee, about the present Benton, in Polk county, Tennessee.
uwâ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—hand, paw; generally used with the possessive suffix, as uwâye&mlprime;n&ibreve;, “his hand.”
uwe&mlprime;la—liver.
uwe&mlprime;năh&ibreve;—rich; used also as a personal name as the equivalent of Richard. Cf. Tsuwe&mlprime;năh&ibreve;.
Uw&mlapos;tsûñ&mlprime;tă,—“Bouncer” (habitual); from k&okina;ts&ibreve;, “it is bouncing.” A traditional serpent described as moving by jerks like a measuring worm, to which also the name is applied. See number 55.
Uyâhye&mlprime;—a high peak in the Great Smoky range, probably on the line between Swain county, North Carolina, and Sevier or Blount county, Tennessee. See number 75 and notes.
Uy&mlapos;gilâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;—abbreviated from Tsuyu&okina;gilâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;, “Where there are dams,” i.e., beaver dams; from gu&okina;gilû&mlprime;ûñskû&mlprime;, “he is damming it.” 1. A former settlement on Oothcaloga (Ougillogy) creek of Oostanaula river, near the present Calhoun, in Gordon county, Georgia; 2. Beaverdam creek, west of Clarkesville, in Habersham county, Georgia.
Valleytown—see Gû&mlprime;nahitûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Vengeance creek—see Gănsa&okina;ti&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Wachesa—see Watsi&mlprime;sŭ.
wadâñ&mlprime;—thanks!
wâ&mlprime;d&ibreve;—paint, especially red paint.
wâ&mlprime;dige-askâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;—“his head (is) brown,” i.e., “brown-head,” from wâdige&mlprime;&ibreve;, brown, brown-red, and askâ&mlprime;l&ibreve;, possessive of uskă&mlprime;, head; the copperhead snake.
Wadi&mlprime;yăh&ibreve;—A feminine name of doubtful etymology. An expert basket-making woman among the East Cherokee, who died in 1895. She was known to the whites as Mrs Bushyhead. See page 179.
Wafford—see Tsuskwanûñ&mlprime;năwa&mlprime;tă.
Wa&mlprime;g&ibreve;ns&ibreve;&mlprime;—The name of an eddy at the junction of the Little Tennessee and main Tennessee rivers, at Lenoir, in Loudon county, Tennessee. The town is now known to the Cherokee by the same name, of which the meaning is lost. See number 124.
wagul&ibreve;&mlprime;—whippoorwill; the name is an onomatope; the Delaware name is wekolis (Heckewelder).
Wahnenauhi—see Wani&mlprime;năh&ibreve;.
wa&okina;huhu&mlprime;—the screech-owl (Megascops asio); see also tsk&ibreve;l&ibreve;&mlprime; and uguku&mlprime;.
wa&okina;ka—cow; from the Spanish vaca, as is also the Creek waga and the Arapaho wakûch.
walâ&mlprime;s&ibreve;—the common green frog; there are different names for the bullfrog (kûnu&mlprime;nŭ, q.v.) and for other varieties; warts are also called walâ&mlprime;s&ibreve;.
Walâsi&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Frog place.” 1. A former settlement, known to the whites as Frogtown, upon the creek of the same name, north of Dahlonega, in Lumpkin county, Georgia. 2. Le Conte and Bullhead mountains in the Great Smoky range on the North Carolina-Tennessee line, together with the ridge extending into Sevier county, Tennessee, between the Middle and West forks of Little Pigeon river. See number 51 and notes.
walâs&mlprime;-unûl&mlprime;st&ibreve;—“it fights frogs,” from walâ&mlprime;s&ibreve;, frog, and unûl&mlprime;st&ibreve;, “it fights” (habitually); gû&okina;lihû&mlprime;, “I am fighting.” The Prosartes lanuginosa plant. See number 126.
Walâs&mlprime;-unûlsti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Place of the plant walâs&mlprime;-unûl&mlprime;st&ibreve;,” commonly known to the whites as Fightingtown, from a translation of the latter part of the name; a former settlement on Fightingtown creek, near Morganton, in Fannin county, Georgia. See number 125.
Walin&ibreve;&mlprime;—a feminine name, compounded from Wal&ibreve;, another form of Kwal&ibreve;, “Polly,” with a suffix added for euphony.
Wane&mlprime;-asûñ&mlprime;tlûñy&ibreve;—“Hickory footlog place,” from wane&mlprime;&ibreve;, hickory, asûñtlûñ&mlprime;&ibreve; (q.v.), footlog, bridge, and y&ibreve;, locative. A former settlement, known to the whites as Hickory-log, on Etowah river, a short distance above Canton, in Cherokee county, Georgia.
Wani&mlprime;năh&ibreve;&mlprime;—a feminine name of uncertain etymology; the Wahnenauhi of the Wahnenauhi manuscript.
Washington—see Wa&mlprime;sitû&mlprime;nă.
Wâ&mlprime;s&ibreve;—the Cherokee form for Moses.
Wa&mlprime;sitû&mlprime;nă, Wa&mlprime;sûñtû&mlprime;nă (different dialectic forms)—a Cherokee known to the whites as Washington, the sole survivor of a Removal tragedy. See page 158. The name denotes a hollow log (or other cylindrical object) lying on the ground at a distance; the root of the word is asi&mlprime;ta, log, and the w prefixed makes it at a distance.
Wa&mlprime;sulû&mlprime;—a large red-brown moth which flies about the blossoming tobacco in the evening.
Watâ&mlprime;g&ibreve; (commonly written Watauga, also Watoga, Wattoogee, Whatoga, etc.)—a name occurring in two or more towns in the old Cherokee country; one was an important settlement on Watauga creek of Little Tennessee river, a few miles below Franklin, in Macon county, Tennessee; another was traditionally located at Watauga Old Fields, about the present Elizabethton, on Watauga river, in Carter county, Tennessee. See page 21. The meaning of the name is lost.
Watauga—see Watâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
Watsi&mlprime;să—a prominent old Cherokee, known to the whites as Wachesa, a name which cannot be translated, who formerly lived on lower Beaverdam creek of Hiwassee river, below Murphy, in Cherokee county, North Carolina. From the fact that the Unicoi turnpike passed near his place it was locally known as the Wachesa trail.
wa&okina;ya—wolf; the name is an onomatope, intended as an imitation of the animal's howl; cf. the Creek name, yähä.
Wa&okina;yâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Wolf place,” i.e. place of the Wolf clan; the form Ani&mlprime;-Wa&okina;yâ&mlprime;h&ibreve; is not used. Wolftown settlement on upper Soco creek, on the East Cherokee reservation, in Jackson county, North Carolina.
Waya gap—see A&okina;tâhi&mlprime;ta.
Wayeh—see Wây&ibreve;.
Wâyî—“Pigeon”; the modern Cherokee name for Big Pigeon river in western North Carolina; probably a translation of the English name. It appears also as Wayeh.
Welch, Lloyd—see Da&mlprime;si&okina;giya&mlprime;g&ibreve;.
wesă—cat; a corruption of “pussy.”
White-path—see Nûñnâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;-tsune&mlprime;ga.
Willstown—a former important settlement, so called from the halfbreed chief known to the whites as Red-headed Will, on Will's creek below Fort Payne, in Dekalb county, Alabama. The settlement was frequently called from him Wili&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Will's place,” but this was not the proper local name.
W&ibreve;ls&ibreve;n&ibreve;&mlprime;—the Cherokee name for H. W. Spray, agent and superintendent for the East Cherokee reservation; an adaptation of his middle name, Wilson.
Wil-usdi&mlprime;—“Little Will,” from Wil&ibreve;&mlprime;, Will and usdi&mlprime;ga or usdi&mlprime;, little. The Cherokee name for Colonel W. H. Thomas, for many years the recognized chief of the eastern band.
Wissactaw—see găhăw&ibreve;&mlprime;sita.
Wolftown—see Wa&okina;yâ&mlprime;h&ibreve;.
Wootassite, Wrosetasatow—see Outacity.
Wude&mlprime;ligûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—the west; literally “there where it (the sun) goes down” (w prefixed implies distance, y&ibreve;, locative). See also Usûñhi&mlprime;y&ibreve; and wusûhihûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Wuliga&mlprime;nătûtûñ—excelling all others, either in good or bad; it may be used as equivalent to wastûñ, “beyond the limit.” See page 232.
wusûhihûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“there where they stay over night,” i.e. “the west.” An archaic term used by the narrator of the story of Ûñtsaiy&ibreve;&mlprime;, number 63. The common word is wude&mlprime;ligûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, q.v., while the term in the sacred formulas is Usûñhi&mlprime;y&ibreve;, q.v.
Xuala—see Ani-Suwa&mlprime;l&ibreve;.
-yă—a suffix denoting principal or real, as tsiskwa&mlprime;yă, “principal bird,” the sparrow; Ani&mlprime;-Yûñwiyă&mlprime;, “principal or real people,” Indians.
Yahoola—see Yahulâ&mlprime;&ibreve;.
Yahulâ&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Yahu&mlprime;la place,” from Yahu&mlprime;la, a Cherokee trader said to have been taken by the spirit people; Yahu&mlprime;la seems to be from the Creek yoho&mlprime;lo, a name having reference to the song (yoholo), used in the “black drink” ceremony of the Creeks; thus a&mlprime;si-yoho&mlprime;lo, corrupted into Osceola, signified “the black drink song”; it may, however, be a true Cherokee word, yahu&mlprime;lû, or yahu&mlprime;l&ibreve;, the name for a variety of hickory, also for the “doodle-bug”; Ûñyahu&mlprime;lă is a feminine name, but can not be translated. Yahoola creek, near Dahlonega, in Lumpkin county, Georgia. See number 86 and notes.
Yalâ&mlprime;g&ibreve;—Alarka creek of Little Tennessee river, above the junction of Tuckasegee, in Swain county, North Carolina; the meaning of the name is lost.
yañdaska&mlprime;ga—a faultfinder. See number 61.
Yân-e&mlprime;gwa—“Big-bear,” from yânû, bear, and egwa, great, large. A prominent chief about the year 1800; the name occurs in treaties as Yonah, Yohanaqua and Yonahequah. See page 164.
yâ&mlprime;nû—bear.
Yâ&mlprime;nû-din&ebreve;hûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the bears live,” from yânû, bear, din&ebreve;hû&mlprime;, “they dwell” (&ebreve;&mlprime;hû, “I dwell, I live”), and y&ibreve;, locative. A place on Oconaluftee river, a short distance above the junction with Tuckasegee, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Yânûgûñ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;—“The bear drowns him” (habitually), from yânû, bear, and tsigûñ&mlprime;iskă&mlprime;, “I am drowning him.” A noted East Cherokee chief, known to the whites as Yonaguska or Drowning-bear. See page 162.
Yâ&mlprime;nû-u&mlprime;nătawasti&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the bears wash” (from yânû, bear, and y&ibreve;, locative); a former pond in the Great Smoky mountains, about the extreme head of Raven fork, in Swain county, North Carolina. See number 122.
yân&mlprime;-utse&mlprime;stû—“the bear lies on it”; the shield fern (Aspidium). See number 126.
Yawâ&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Yawă place”; a place on Yellow creek of Cheowa river, in Graham county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Yellow-hill—see Elăwâ&mlprime;diy&ibreve;.
Yohanaqua—see Yân-e&mlprime;gwa.
yoho-o!—an unmeaning song refrain. See number 75.
Yonaguska—see Yâ&mlprime;nûgûñ&mlprime;sk&ibreve;.
Yonah—1. (mountain) see Gadalu&mlprime;lŭ. 2. An abbreviated treaty form for the name of the chief Yân-e&mlprime;gwa.
Yonahequah—see Yân-e&mlprime;gwa.
Ytaua, Ytava—see I&mlprime;tăwă&mlprime;.
Yu!—an unmeaning song refrain and interjection.
Yuha&mlprime;l&ibreve;—Euharlee creek, of lower Etowah river, in Bartow county, Georgia. The name is said by the Cherokee to be a corruption of Yufala (Eufaula), a well-known Creek local name. See number 105.
yûnsû&mlprime;—buffalo; cf. Creek y&ebreve;na&mlprime;sa, Choctaw yanash, Hichitee ya&mlprime;nasi.
Yûnsâ&mlprime;&ibreve;—“Buffalo place”; West Buffalo creek of Cheowa river in Graham county, North Carolina; the site of a former Cherokee settlement. See number 122.
yu&mlprime;w&ebreve;-yuw&ebreve;he&mlprime;—an unmeaning song refrain. See number 118.
yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;—person, man; cf. Mohawk oñgwe&okina;.
Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve; Amă&mlprime;y&ibreve;n&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;—“Water-dwelling People,” from yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;, person, and ămă&mlprime;y&ibreve;n&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;, plural of ămăy&ebreve;&mlprime;h&ibreve;, q.v.; a race of water fairies. See number 78.
Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;-d&ibreve;katâgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—see Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;-tsulenûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;.
Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve; Gûnăhi&mlprime;ta—“Long Man”; a formulistic name for the river, personified as a man with his head resting on the mountain and his feet stretching down to the lowlands, who is constantly speaking to those who can understand the message.
Yûñ&mlprime;wini&mlprime;gisk&ibreve;—“Man-eaters,” literally, “They eat people” (habitually), from yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;, person, man, and uni&mlprime;gisk&ibreve;, “they eat” (habitually), from ts&ibreve;kiû&mlprime;, “I am eating”; the Cherokee name for a distant cannibal tribe, possibly the Atakapa or the Tonkawa. See number 105. Cf. Anăda&mlprime;dûñtăsk&ibreve;.
Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;-tsulenûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;—“Where the man stood,” originally Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;-d&ibreve;katâgûñ&mlprime;y&ibreve;, “Where the man stands,” from yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;, person, man, tsitâ&mlprime;gă, “I am standing,” and y&ibreve;, locative; Standing Indian, a high bald mountain at the head of Nantahala river, in Macon county, North Carolina. See number 122.
Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve; Tsunsdi&mlprime;—“Little People,” from yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;, person, people, and tsunsdi&mlprime;gă or tsunsdi&mlprime;, plural of usdi&mlprime;gă, or usdi&mlprime;, little; the Cherokee fairies. See number 78.
Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve; Usd&ibreve;&mlprime;—“Little Man.” A formulistic name for the ginseng, â&mlprime;tăl&ibreve;-gûl&ibreve;&mlprime;, q.v.
Yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;-usga&mlprime;s&ebreve;&okina;t&ibreve;—“Dangerous Man, Terrible Man”; a traditional leader in the westward migration of the Cherokee. See page 99.
Yûñ&mlprime;wiyă&mlprime;—“Indian,” literally, “principal or real person,” from yûñ&mlprime;w&ibreve;, person and yă, a suffix denoting principal or real. See pages 15 and 181.
